Fahrenheit by Christian Dior is a Woody Floral Musk fragrance for men. Fahrenheit was launched in 1988. Fahrenheit was created by Jean-Louis Sieuzac and Maurice Roger. Top notes are lavender, mandarin orange, hawthorn, nutmeg flower, cedar, bergamot, chamomile and lemon; middle notes are nutmeg, honeysuckle, carnation, sandalwood, violet leaf, jasmine, lily-of-the-valley and cedar; base notes are leather, tonka bean, amber, patchouli, musk and vetiver.

Perfume rating: 3.89 out of 5 with 6015 votes.

Fahrenheit Fragrance Reviews

SirMasterpiece

@TheDemagogue,

Your wardrobe consist in fresh, synthetic, easy-to-wear, mass-pleasers galore...and YOU have the guts to talk about Fahrenheit like that?!

Just think again about you've just said...

Jul
11
2017
The Demagogue

Tremendously overrated, massively overvalued and remarkably over-worn. If this didn't have the name Dior etched on the bottle, a lot of these snowflakes on fragrantica wouldn't even bother with it unless it was repackaged as an overpriced niche obscurity. A lot of people have allergies to the violet leaf and honeysuckle combination in this, so you need to be tremendously careful before making this one a blind buy. if you like the smell of burning gasoline, and so many of us as kids did, then you may find something that really triggers your memory here and brings you back to your younger years..But don't be taken fully by this Jedi mind-trick, this is a risky wear for the modern male under 40 trying to break into the 30 and under female market. Ivanka totally did not like this and I gave Jared a bottle of Creed instead. Yes, it will continue to get remarkable and amazing reviews here because of the respectability with the middle-class Dior invokes & implies, but truth be told this one will date you on the Eastern European mail order bride websites come meeting time.

Jul
11
2017
Norstrm

Opium... Bel Ami... Fahrenheit!

Sieuzac was not prolific, but with icons like that on his CV, he could easily make many a nose green with envy.

Fahrenheit was a rebel when it was released, and it still is to this day. A true gamechanger. Not just in the world of fragrance, but probably also for many of the wearers. I know it changed a lot for me.

Fahrenheit was probably the scent, that made me realise, that fragrances are not just nice smells; they can be art and stir one's emotions.

How evocative it was! That almost chameleonic ability to morph between gentle florals and creamy woods, and into a leatherjacket wearing, lawn-mowing animal.

Many say it is more of a winter fragrance, but to me it has always screamed "SUMMER!" From the first spray years ago, it has always conjured up the image of fresh cut grass and a petrol-driven lawn mower. When I need to feel and smell the summer, this is what I reach for.

Ever since that first day, it has been a mainstay of my evergrowing collection, always hanging on to the top, as one of my true favourites.

They say first loves never truly die.

When it comes to Fahrenheit, the saying is most fitting; I will always love this one and have it in my collection.

PS: My mum thought it smelled like pickled cucumbers.

Jul
11
2017
Scentim3nt4l

One of my newfound loves. I have never really strayed towards Dior fragrances much but this has won me over. Really unique and masculine. Reminds me of hot tarmac, the smell and atmosphere before a storm erupts, its incredible. Dior has managed to capture the essence of heat in a fragrance. Its stunning, lasts all day and gets tons of compliments when i wear it. Its a icon.

Jul
07
2017
Beyonder

One of my favorite designer fragrances of all times.
This is so masculine, unique and distinctive. I have smelled nearly 500 different fragrances since the 80's and nothing is similar to this.
If you are the kind of guy who worry about offending someone with your scent please stay away from it because some people don't like the gasoline vibe it contains but if you wear fragrances for yourself you must try this. A true Masterpiece in the world of perfumery. Thumbs up!

Coppa

I really really really like this fragrance. It it quite unique but it reminds me of one of my uncles who has weared this fragrance forever so I don't buy it. It has the potential of being a signature scent and it could very possibly be mine but i'm so picky with my fragrances that when it reminds me of something I don't like (even though the scent is great) I just end up leaving it at the store. Incredible scent though.

emmanuel.ramos.148

This will be the one fragrance that will never be missing on my list. since I was a child, around 10+ yrs old (1996+), my older brother used to purchase this fragrance and ever since has been my favorite. I remember we used to argue a lot, cause I used to use it up when he wasn't around and this used to cause his bottle to run out faster. out of all my fragrances this has been one of my main woman's attention grabber, almost every woman I know is attracted by this fragrance and loves it. till this day, this fragrance still stands strong on it's own level of sophistication, class and luxury, which is none the more than what this fragrance speaks for it's self.

Silage:8 = within 6 feet for the first 3+ hours, to a very noticeable arms length
Longevity:9 = 12++ hours for me
Scent:9 = masculine, attractive and characteristic.
Versatility: mild to cold temperature. Night out clubbing, to out with a woman.

Jun
28
2017
Luna_J

I came across these as well, so, I stand corrected, though I should point our that there is a pretty massive difference between 25% and 60%. For reference, the same sources list Terre d'Hermes as 55% and Encre Noire at 45%... If you know those compositions, it is easy to see the difference between fragrances that use this ingredient for mostly technical reasons and those that are aesthetically constructed *around* it. The idea of foregrounding a blatantly synthetic molecule in such an obvious way is pretty postmodern, as opposed to the more slight-of-hand segues between naturalism and synthetic innovations such as coumarin in the earliest fougere compositions, the jasmine-based Hedione in Eau Sauvage or lyral which smells like lily-of-the-valley and contributed to the famous 'honeysuckle' accord in the original formulation of Fahrenheit, for that matter.

Jun
23
2017
AutumnForCrippledChildren

@ Luna J If you look at the Wikipedia page of ISO E Super, they list a bunch of fragrances that contain the ingredient. It states that Dior Fahrenheit contains 25% ISO E Super. I had no idea until a few years ago. Hope that helped.

Jun
23
2017
Milu666

Oh boy, the reformulations simply destroyed this fragrance. What Dior has done to Fahrenheit is even worse than what JPG did to Le Male. I used to love this perfume back in the day. It was 1996, I was in highschool and the boy I liked used to bath in this cologne, the smell of gasoline was so unusual, but at the same time fascinating and so unique! The drydown was so rich and powerful that I couldn't help but to love i! Now Fahrenheit is just a shadow of its former self. The gasoline accord has been so toned down that's barely even there, the scent lost its complexity and deepness. Shame on you, Dior!

Jun
21
2017
Luna_J

@ Ghylama,
I am curious as to where you heard this statistic about ISO in Fahrenheit. I have never detected any obvious quantity of it in any of the formulations I've owned (: early and late1990's; 2014).

Compositions that rely heavily on ISO like Lalique Encre Noire, Terre d"Hermes, and Cartier Declaration all have that discernible 'buzz' of sawdusty cedar and woody-sweet musk that is quite recognizable once you've picked it out. It is as much a radiating texture as a scent, which is one of the qualities that has made it quite popular in the last fifteen years or more.

I'm slightly allergic to ISO, so I pick it up very quickly, and doubt that (despite its lamentable ubiquity as an 'easy-reach' for perfumers these days) Dior would see fit to add it to a reformulation of Fahrenheit, as its very specific scent, dynamism and texture impact Fahrenheit's scent profile considerably. [Update: looks like I was wrong! But has it really been there since the late 80's? This composition has been doctored pretty severely since the 2000's, notably to restrict lyral and birch tar...)

As for a rubber tire smell, that is more likely some synthetic approximation of Fahrenheit's birch tar you are smelling; that, or the infamous vanilla note that showed up in the early teens when Dior seemed to be trying to nudge the original formula a tad closer to Fahrenheit's darker and more 'night'-oriented Parfum and Absolute flankers.

Jun
19
2017
Ghylama

Smells like tires somehow on clothes. To be studied more thoroughly. Apparently this is 60% Iso-E super.

John Wayne 86

19
2017
Donjuandemarco

Man oh man... I am writing this review after 2 minutes i sprayed a vintage version on 1994, freshly unboxed!

Having a Nosegasm my hands are trembling, body is shaking haha WOW! I couldn't guess how the vintage is Soo different thousand of miles, light years far away from the current formula. I like exaggereting if you didn't notice :)

Okey let's get down to it. Lit a cigarette, it blends so nice with smoke :) Dry leather with with a little touch of florals and benzin, sweet benzin leather,gas station covered with deer leathers with a shy sweetness at the opening but this kind of natural smelling leather i didn't come across even in TF Tuscan leather or Acqua di parma leather cologne.. Its so natural like you buy a new car with leather seats and you have just ripped off the celophene from the seats. PERFECT

I also get a lot of musk as in Narciso Rodrigez for him EDP so dry, animalistic, sexy. Yeah it definitely makes me feel sexy or like an animal hunting down a partner in the woods while the entire wood is on fire and every other animal else are running away for their lives but not caring in that moment.. Just focused on pairing and feeling strong as if flames don't get to you.

I couldn't wait till drydown so for the first 15 mins it gave me that kind of mood.. My god, worth every single penny!


To be continued...

EDIT:
Lo: 10+ hours with 2 sprays
Si: 4 hours good then close to the skin but i get whiffs occasionally

i wore it yesterday on a rainy day with high humidity only 1 spray on the chest and it was not overwhelmed . Pleasent and soft

I am curious about Aqua Fahrenheit, haven't seen it in any shops around yet. If it's even 50% like Fahrenheit it would be my go to summer frag.

Jun
16
2017
The Lorax

1988, yes that is when I started wearing this. All I can say is that it is an all time great. I love it, and will always have a bottle.

There is a leathery, petroleum smell, but don't let that persuade you to not try it. People either like it or they dont, and imo, it is impossible to describe the scent via verbage, or listing of the notes.

It is both dark, and light, and can be worn at any time of the day, or year.

Nothing else ever has smelled like this, and nothing ever will.

It is Dior Man's crown jewel, and does not even belong in the category of "designer fragrence."

It is that good.

2017
Nawal.Ansari

Biggest balls in the Dior family.

Fahrenheit opens up with a blast of lavender and citruses, giving it a burning gasoline vibe. Once it settles down, it is a lovely mixture of various notes and smells extremely masculine and gorgeous. I would see a masculine guy on a bike wearing a leather jacket wearing this,or a car mechanic. Doesn't mean than you can't wear this otherwise, but please sample this one because it can be polarizing.

Scent - 9/10
Performance - 7/10
Presentation - 9/10

Manliest fragrance from the Dior house. Go easy on the sprayer and enjoy this masterpiece.

bubbagump210

Gasoline opening is right. Woof. If you apply this via a swab/cotton ball and don't spray, it is more pleasant. The top notes do smell just like a 2 cycle engine. However, the mid notes are wonderful spicy/woody. The question is, can you stand the top notes? I'm not sure that I can.

nerd9891

Couldn't stand the smell of it the first time smelled it. The gas smell was too much. Tried it again a few months later, but with the same result. Years later I'm in a locker room and smell something so nice and pleasant, I had to ask the person wearing it what it was. "Fahrenheit," he replied. Couldn't believe it. Went to a store to retest it, and finally the beauty of the scent hit me. Absolutely stunning! I'm now a proud owner and wearer of Fahrenheit. I will say that this is best smelled from a distance, and not up close because you will get somewhat of a gas smell. For that reason, I say 2-3 sprays max.

alexvpm

Honestly, I don't love Fahrenheit. I'm not a big fan of that characteristic gas smell. It's just not my thing. At first I hated it, I didn't get how come it is been almost 30 years on the market. However and as time goes by, I've been wearing it over and over again and eventually it kind of grew on me. Now, I have respect for the scent because I realized it really deserves its spot. it is a completely timeless, complex, well-done, high-quality and unique fragrance. Sincerely, now I understand there might be people out there who love this perfume. I still don't love it, but I know it definitely is a solid fragrance.

P.D: Fahrenheit commercials are BEAUTIFUL, especially Erick Ifergan's which is my favorite perfume ad. I highly recommend you to watch it if you haven't.

Objective rating: 5/5
Personal rating: 4/5

Noa23

This is a bottle of sexy mysterious confidence. Women love it. No other fragrance I ever wore got me so many compliments and so many girls smelling my neck and chest after a passionate night clutching tight on me with a last deep comfortable breath and a sigh before falling asleep.
Fahrenheit is a magical scent on skin, mature and sexy and not over masculine. It keeps the balance perfectly and warms up and softens after a few hours without losing the leather note. It's not necessary to use a lot, the sillage is perfectly intimate and lingers the whole night.
Make Your lovers happy and get a bottle.

Chazas

@meliecat

Strong statement, there is no need to be that stereotypical, putting labels on this and that.

Fahrenheit for me was the fragrance that made me appreciate and look into fragrances not only as scents, but as a pleasure, hobby, signature, expression, obsession and adventure.

And that was still when I was a teenager, so maybe spaying Fahrenheit on myself made me from this faint-hearted boy to a man? lacking courage person wound not wear a Fahrenheit or any unique scent in the first place, right? just a thought.

In my eyes, fragrances have no age limit nor label, it is absolutely personal, age does not make you a man nor masculine, but a lifestyle, personality, goals and achievements, I have seen far more manlier guys in all, even at young age, compared to others even when twice the age. Age is just a number.

Basically, even a female could pull it of, if that would be hers preference or if that would reflect her, it would not be what I would like to smell on a female, as my preference goes, but I would respect that.

Anyways, what an amazing and unique fragrance Fahrenheit is, a true benchmark, only one thing you need for it, just to grow a nose to appreciate it.

May
13
2017
Myloric

I Just got a 6.8 oz bottle of this from 2013. Am loving it. Previously added a sample from my perfume samples and became hooked. Initially I steered away from this because I had noted the gasoline note on previous reviews and such. People seem to love it or hate it. Upon first whiff I fell into the love category. Hence I got the biggest bottle that I could get. The so called gasoline petrol note that I was afraid of, often wondering why anyone would want to smell like that, while it is present is not the draw to it. It's the whole complexity. You look at the notes that are involved in creating this. It's the I have no idea what I am smelling but I love it. I am inexperienced when it comes to reviews, and notes. I just know that this one is a masterpiece and I am proud to have a bottle of it. I have been searching and searching for that one scent that suits me and I have just found it. It's just become my signature.

Edit: Have added more bottles of this masterpiece for I never want to run out and some durations seem to last more than others. I now have 3 6.8 oz bottles one is half full plus a 1.7 oz travel one. I fill a travalo decant with a little from my big bottles so that when it begins to fade can reapply as needed. Ordered my first pre 2010 formulation as well just a 3.4 oz but somewhere I read that the earlier batches lasted longer. And I just love this juice.

May
07
2017
Oldspice

Classic Fahrenheit was one of those intriguing fragrances with a mix of clean and dirty notes like Kouros. A leathery fragrance with a clean side that reminds me of a bar soap I used in my childhood. The dirty side smelled like used motor oil. In theory that doesn't sound appealing but I grew to like it and always seemed to garner compliments from women somehow.

I recently purchased a 2016 bottle after hearing that it had been improved compared to bottles from recent years. It is still watered down. I remember using 2 or so sprays of vintage and now 5, 6 sprays have good longevity but still don't project like I remember it. The scent is mostly true to vintage but the dirty oil note that made it unique is greatly reduced.

Edit: Don't care for the dry-down on this much. The nutmeg disappears and I'm left with this wet, musky leather.

Apr
21
2017
BigBootsie

Easily ,

I just bought a bottle of Dior Fahrenheit today at Sephora for my birthday present. I'm a long time appreciator of men's fragrances and "lurker" here at this site, so you can take my review with a grain of salt or however you see fit, seeing as how I'm definitely not an expert. To begin with, I'm plenty old enough (52!) to have worn this juice when it originally launched, but missed it somehow. In the late 80's I was all about my motorcycle, black leather jacket and playing in a band in the sweaty downtown clubs (there's a scent for ya).

Dior Fahrenheit is to me a perfect men's fragrance, even more so now that is nearly thirty years old and nothing like what the other "houses" are selling and what everyone else is wearing for that matter. Reformulated? Probably ten times, but I don't care because it smells so good and so different from everything else. It is manly, leathery with traces of a slight musk in the drydown. Yes, there is a petrol vibe here, but motorcycling is still my passion, so that only adds to the scent. It is both earthy and... so not. The strongest notes I pick up are leather, petrol, something green and something musky. I use about four to six sprays on average and it lasts for most of the day, starting off with a somewhat citrusy blast that mellows down and really changes over the day into a wonderful and unique scent.
Longevity- 8 plus hours
Sillage- 3 feet for 4 hours
Batch code 6N01 = January 2016

Apr
20
2017
konkok

Masterpiece! I do 6-8 sprays , it last me all day with the late 2016 version. Ladies recognize it especially if they are like 40-50 years old.

Apr
17
2017
steventuckwellmobile

I've just opened the door and sat down behind the wheel of a classic Rolls. That's why I smell petrol, leather, and wood. It's summer time, and its warm, so I'm mostly catching the lightest and most volatile components of those aromas.

The bees are busy in the garden on this fine day, collecting pollen from the fragrant, blooming flowers. Because it's summer, there's also a table nearby with a jug of iced water and a fruit bowl set upon it, filled with citrus fruits, and my nose is just faintly aware of their presence.

All is well with world, and I take moment to appreciate how satisfied I am.

assim.hayderi

Just bought my 100ml bottle for appr. 38 dollars. I tried this one for the first time back in 2011 and I instantly fell in love with how unique and masculine it was. I never bought it because the price was too high (being a designer perfume). I bought Dior Fahrenheit Absolut for a good price (100ml for 48 dollars) from a girl but I was disappointed as the Absolut version was strong and disgusting. I agree with people saying that it smells gasoline, to some extent, but to me, it smells more like a mixture of woods, rubber and leather. Dirty in a classy way. A masterpiece I would say.

Scent: 9/10
Longevity: 9/10
Projection: 8.5/10

Mar
29
2017
Smellinggoodislife

Still stunningly amazing even today. I've only found 1 cologne ever that could compete with Fahrenheit or better it, and that was Happy. Otherwise this is the pinnacle of incredible smelling cologne formulations. It's so sexy, unique, refined, masculine, incredible smelling, and DIFFERENT than anything else in the world. I just bought another big sized bottle from Target, and I'm back to being simply, the best smelling man anywhere. "Dior", there is no substitute after making this incredible scent...................

On a scale from 1-10, It's a 20. You can't rate something that smells this great and amazing. It's just one of those very few colognes ever, that's better than everything else.

And also, this scent does not faintly smell like gasoline, or petroleum at all, no chance, not even a hint. If you think it smells like gasoline, your high (yes high on drugs) and or have completely lost your sense of smell at birth or to a freak acccident. It does have a nice burnt amber and leather smell to it.

Scent:20 out of 10
Longevity:9
Sillage:8
Unique/Industry First:10
Quality:10

johntsoumanis

...fall 2016...
I ordered Mont Blanc's Individuel(great by the way)and they also sent a 5ml sample of Fahrenheit.
...Sprayed the sample and i was in heaven...So fucking great, so fucking unique, so fucking masculine frag.

Bought my first bottle in early December 2016(6Q03)from duty free and the second one in Feb 2017(6T01)from attica stores in Athens Greece(they had this on sale, 58euro for 100ml.) So im talking about the latest formulation and new box.

upon application i get this amazing combo of ingredients that simply makes me horny ,makes my day. I also love the smokey woody vibe i later get with this frag.

Logenvity is great but projection is moderate. I go a bit heavy with the spays so problem solved. I hope it also works in the summertime. Otherwise i'll go with the aqua or cologne versions.

Simply great!!! 20/10

Overall 7.5/10

2017
HyacinthBucket

I worked for Christian Dior when Fahrenheit was the blockbuster of the era. I loved it and wore it constantly. Although made for men, we were directed to market the fragrance as unisex at a time when the term "unisex" only applied to hair salons.

I'll never forget the time a young lady came in saying, "I'd like to try Fahrenheit", adding with complete innocence, "It's bisexual."

2017
The Revenant99

Let's get something straight right of the bat. This is a " Man's " cologne. The scent screams Alpha from every possible direction. Gasoline, vintage leather, motor oil, and fresh cut grass with Violet leaf smoothing it out perfectly. It is an absolutely timeless masterpiece that has stood the tests of time, and will continue to do so. This is the Mike Tyson of colognes in my opinion. Its the best ever. Its the most brutal and vicious, and most ruthless champion there's ever been. There's no one that can stop it. It's the best ever.There's never been a cologne as ruthless. Peace!!

17
2017
zesty_calco

Florals, leather, wood and musk. Gasoline simulated with flowers; weird; very cool. Masculine, more mature; maybe a little stuffy but I'd still enjoy smelling this on a lady. Smells like "my uncle" or "church pews" (so I've been told). Few compliments; this is one I wear for myself. I think Fahrenheit is my favorite fragrance due to it's evolution and uniqueness but it's not the most wearable. Easy on the sprayer. Starts off heady and pungent; almost a clean scent at the finish. Lasts me all day; good projection and sillage. Works all seasons and most situations. Possibly not a work or first date scent as it's quite bold. Sprayer is Dior quality. Bottle, name/concept are well designed. There's a reason why this one is a classic!

Mar
16
2017
Peek Freans

This dichotomy of Fahrenheits essence is represented in its two most dominant opening notes. The first is no surprise if youve already read some reviews and were expecting gasoline. However, think of this note more as motor spirit (which happens to be what British refiners originally called gasoline). It just sounds more romantic that way and befitting of the low-octane version of the liquid that fuels this fragrance. The effect is something akin to that industrial smell of freshly burned petrol, but more lovable lawnmower than dirty diesel pump in quality and intensity. Violet, the second principal top note and typical of its shrinking nature, introduces itself gently as a fallen leaf on the surface of a calm pond (of motor oil er, spirit). It is nearly impossible to imagine how this marriage of gasoline and synthetic violet can harmonize without first-hand experience of it in bloom. However, someone recently told me that salt and pepper go well on sliced apples, so odder couples have consummated before (like Cheetohs and milk), but I digress. Perhaps theres no rational to its happy synergy, or perhaps its the omnipresent leather accord throughout the drydown that serves as a medium between the two leading notes.

This is a true modern classic that unfortunately a lot of younger guys are unaware of and would love it if they would only try something on other than AXE. Its dual nature makes it appropriate for both the horny teen w/ pit stains stuttering out an invitation to prom to his high school crush and the young urban family man who wants to keep some effervescence alive in his marriage. Go pick out a bottle or two, they even sell it at drug stores!

Mar
06
2017
Estela B

Back in the 90's when I was a teenager me and my girl friends used this even though it was a male fragrance. i had a bottle and used all of it. I recommend it, I don't know how is the formula today, but it was really good.

Mar
03
2017
Yourhumblenarrator

The official smell of the Mad Max films. Dior is known for their unique, bold and daring fragrances, and this is perhaps perfectly exemplified by the volcanic glass bottle that is Dior Fahrenheit. The oily petrol note is understandably what makes or breaks Fahrenheit for everyone. Some get gasoline, others get a greasy mechanic vibe, and I myself am reminded of a vintage can of old shoe polish that my dad kept around, a scent that I enjoy but not necessarily in perfume form. Violet and other florals are present to tame the beast, but are equally sharp and very grassy. It's like a greasy old lawnmower ripping and roaring through a field of flowers.

At the end of the day Fahrenheit is just too heavy for me. I love the smell of gasoline as much as the next weirdo, but in small doses. It's not something I want hovering around me for hours and this is just far too realistic. Artistic credit is undeniably due, but my fragile brain seems to recognize this as fumes. I'm put off but going to spend some more time with it though I think the parfum flanker is much more my speed.

Mar
01
2017
ActiveX101

After reading countless reviews of this almost mythical fragrance, I knew I had to try it. By "try" I don't mean get a tester - I wanted to jump in and just bought a 50ml bottle to get a real idea of what all the talk is about. This is a brand new 2016 bottle, so that obviously means it's the reformulation, though I've heard that the 2016 formula is closer to the original that it's been in a while.

People use all kinds of ridiculous, hyperbolic language to describe Fahrenheit. That's not me, and I'm not really a fragrance aficionado. I just appreciate the sensory pleasure of a nice scent. So I'll keep this fairly short. Does it smell like gasoline? Yes, very much so for the first hour or so. Pretty much everyone who has smelled this scent on me said the exact same thing about the opening - petroleum. That said, it isn't a bad petroleum smell. It does take a bit of getting used to, but it's a very good smell in my opinion. From there, it slowly transforms into a very nice fragrance. A bit flowery, a bit spicy, a bit leathery. It almost makes me hungry when I smell it. The petroleum note hangs in there the entire time, but it becomes very subdued after an hour. Though rare, you may find that the opening of Fahrenheit is offensive to some people. For that reason, I think this fragrance is better for play rather than work. At the very least you may want to wait until it starts to dry down before going to work with this on.

Is this stuff the most incredible fragrance masterpiece ever created? Nope. I can think of at least a few fragrances which are more complex, interesting and appealing. Will it make women swoon instantly? Again, no. It's WAY over-hyped, in my opinion, but it is a nice, unique fragrance that I certainly enjoy having in my collection for when I want something different and a bit more daring. Worth the money, and I'll absolutely buy a larger bottle once this runs out.

18
2017
Konga5000

Still the King of All Male Scents. Why are the flankers so lame ? Not crazy for Absolute or Aqua. I now only buy "vintage" bottles when I can, but this creation is so strong that even watered down a bit-- it can stand up quite well.

Happy that it's still around.

richmilton

If there was ever a strictly male fragrance this would be in the top 5. Now I know that might upset some women out there that wear this, but it don't change my mind. But again, I prefer ladies to smell like a lady. Is that okay to say in today's PC world? The point is, I know a lot of men that wear this (uncle, friends, business associates, etc) so smelling this on a woman would be strange to me. For you ladies out there that don't get it... imagine your husband or father smelling like Tresor? As for Fahrenheit, it does not smell like gasoline, it smells like flowers dipped in used motor oil soaking on leather sits of a classic muscle car sitting in the hot summer sun. That's what I get out of this. And it will forever be in my top 5 of all time.

keen(nose)

My favorite scent and my first real scent as a young teenager. I remember getting this scent as a 17 year old getting into 21 and up clubs. I did not like this at first but the entire club smelled like fahrenheit then. This was an era where you went to the club and come back smelling like cigarettes. I have bought this scent about 4 times since then. When I first sprayed this on my skin I remembered why I poured diesel or petrol on my arm. That petrol smells goes on strong for an hour and last to remainder of the scent. I then get some florals when that nice petrol smell subsides a bit. This scent last a good 6-7 hours with excellent projection.

Longevity 10/10 6-7 hours
Projection 8.5/10 arm length projection
Sillage 7/10

Feb
01
2017
Faisal Wibowo

Dior Farenheit Review:

One of the best fragrance ever!

Yesterday, I brought this to my office and all of my workmates lost their minds just because how great this frag is.. My boss even begged me to sell it to him directly lol.

The scent is so sophisticated, I really love the premium leather scent which is so similar to the expensive nappa leather seats in BMW 7 series and it blends beautifully with the flowery, and the fruity notes.

Longetivity is great, it lasts 10hrs on my skin and the sillage (projection) is heavy too. Well, heavier than any frags I can remember, a little overpowering at the first spray even.

The perfume is very rare in Indonesia, and I happen to be so lucky getting a 200ml bottle with a decent price.

Score
Scent (40%): 95
Sillage (20%): 91
Longetivity (30%): 90
Value for Money (10%): 72

Overall: 91

Jan
31
2017
AmericanCologneGuy

Fahrenheit by Christian Dior is as relevant and edgy now as it was when it was first introduced.
It's a fantastic composition!
To my amateur nose I get: warm leather & spice, creamy sandalwood, spicy vetiver, musk, a hint of amber, and the hidden secret weapon: powdery violet!
Something about all this creates a gasoline/petroleum vibe that, believe it or not, smells clean! I know! Crazy! It's this clean, masculine, powdery amazing scent!
I don't know how they did it, but it works! And even after at least 3 reformulations, it still is long-lasting with nice sillage.
Well done Christian Dior!

I generally prefer it during the day this winter. It's warming and cool at the same time. The projection and longevity are great. Good amount of compliments.

Overall 9/10

RWF

Finally got my nose on this one...

I get a smoky charcoal smell, similar to the dying embers of a fire. Take that and infuse with florals (Violet being the dominant) and thats what this is. Very masculine.
I actually got to smell fahrenheit absolute before this, so the DNA of the original didn't catch me off guard. Absolute is similar, just sweeter and more spice.
Another comparison you could make to this is Gucci Pour Homme II. I find they are quite similar but Gucci is sweeter and less smoke.
I would definitely see myself wearing this on a night out.

26
2017
HurAcraft

Sampled this recently.

I don't get all the talk about it smelling like "gasoline" or "petrol". severely exaggerated... is there a hint of "gasoline" in there? Yes I suppose so. To me it smelled more floral than anything, in a good way. The smell was somewhat rough/dirty.

I liked the scent but not bottle worthy to me. Why? performance was alright but not great at 6-7 hours. Also I happen to own Uomo by Ferrari which is not identical but in the same vein and a cheapie. Great value for money for something similar.

The Uomo one is smoother and more linear to my nose than Fahrenheit. I guess you could say the Ferrari Uomo is "gentleman" and Fahrenheit "Bad guy/daring" to put it in terms.

I prefer Fahrenheit because its less smooth and dirtier. Not bottle worthy to me though because its similar to the ferrari and a much higher price.

Jan
25
2017
Chazas

Addition:
on a new 2016 batch.

The opening is very smooth, fresh orange with lots of vanilla and feel of cinnamon, soft and a bit sweet, leathery and violet the famous petrol dry-down is still there, but seems a little harsher, specially smelling it from up-close. It is basically still the same Fragrance, that you can recognize in a instant.

Longevity and Projection seems to be a little less strong comparing to 2009/2013 batches, about average +, even my Aqua Fahrenheit batches from 2011/2013 seem to have a better performance in both aspects, will wait for early spring to test further. Don't believe false hype comments about "beast mode" performance, best thing to do, go and test 2015/2016 batches yourselves. Anyways, always going to love Fahrenheit.

2017
jerseyjoe1981

I have always been a fan of this fragrance, but I have had it absent in my life for quite some years now.

To answer everyone's question, no it IS NOT A PROJECTION MONSTER AND ALL THIS HYPE OF VINTAGE. I have purchased from sephora a 3.4 oz bottle manufactured in OCT 2016.

This is water juice. The fragrance is still there, yes, but it is not a projection longevity monster.

Luckily, I enjoy the scent to even care if anyone else can smell it, but I won't be picking a up a new bottle until they fix this problem.

It's a pitty really. I feel like all fragrances now are diluted.

In 2010 I fell in love with an amazing fragrance. Wore it and caused men/women to chase me down for the fragrance. Paid a hefty 250 retail price from this store in NYC that had the same brand name as a crappy band in the 90's.
Life changes.....people began to catch on, popularity took hold, and now that fragrance is a watered down reflection of its former glory. Plus, it's now 250 more!!! Can you believe that??!!

What fragrance am I talking about? Well it's not a mystery anymore, but when I was being chased down it was....lol Aventus R.I.the crowd

Jan
22
2017
Chazas

Lots of comments and questions on new 2016 batches, so I want to share my experience.

Recently bought a new bottle of Fahrenheit batch of July 2016, and... to "my" experience and honest opinion, all those hype comments about magical vintage like batches are not true, specially exaggerated longevity, once again, this is my view.

To me, since I honestly never tried a vintage, 2013 batch was the last really good one, or maybe even 2009/2010. Now it is noticeably different, It does still have that "petrol/gasoline" raw leather/violet vibe in the dry-down, but different and slightly more harsh, the opening now I would say is very smooth gourmandish with orange and sweetness of vanilla and a feel of cinnamon, with only a very average performance on longevity, but will comment more on that later, since i wore new batch only few times. Yet, it is still a one and only Fahrenheit.

Jan
14
2017
earlygreek

My first bottle was purchased, if memory serves, in late 1990. I have not been without a bottle since then. I think of this lovely juice as a "daily driver". A scent that can pass for me regardless of the season or tempature. Many comment on the "gasoline" note which is a fair observation. However this initial fleeting note is the set up for a woodsy musk that hovers beautifully three inches or so off my skin for a good six hours. Dior here has very much created a workhorse masterpiece capable of moving through many moods and space. The wood notes and musk are balanced with a remarkably nuanced touch. I always buy the largest bottle of this I can, and now find myself wearing this juice once a month or so, so a bottle lasts me a good amount of time. I was concerned back in October when I found my admittedly older bottle running low and with hesitation purchased a new bottle. I am old enough now, and have been wearing perfume the better part of 30 years, to be wary of the dreaded reformulation that can occur. I am pleased to say that to my nose it seems little reformulation has taken place, as my new bottle when tested against the old bottle (10 years old? Hard to say) is spot on. For those seeking an alternative to the seeming endless wave of aquatic citrus tonics that litter the perfume landscap (fragrance train wrecks for the most part) sample the fire Dior created many years ago. Still as relevant, cunning, and sexy as ever.

29
2016
sweetsmellingmama

2016
georgequeue

Score: 10/10...enough said!

Dec
21
2016
Strathairn

There is a note in this that is just gorgeous. I'm guessing it's the violet leaf, but I don't have any prior experience with that note so I could be wrong there.

Sometimes I'll put my nose near the atomizer just to get a quick Fahrenheit fix. This stuff makes me feel like a junkie.

It smells like sweet, violet-infused, plasticine leather. Trust me that it smells better than this description makes it sound. It is difficult to describe this fragrance. It doesn't smell like anything else I've come across yet so I can't offer any comparisons. Although a tad sweet for me at times, it doesn't smell like anything else out there which makes it a pleasure to wear.

It toes the line between smelling natural and smelling synthetic, smelling good and smelling a little strange. At times I've been puzzled by the fact that I like it. In the same way that you can like the sweet smell of certain motor oils. It doesn't smell good in a typical way, but it still smells good. For some reason I find that sweet smell of motor oil comforting and I get the same comforting vibe from Fahrenheit.

I always feel a bit conflicted when I wear this. It's like 70% of my brain likes it and 30% thinks it's weird. So there is this sense all the time of "Why do I even like this?" but it consistently gets overruled by the 70% that likes it.

I don't feel this is an uber masculine fragrance. There is something soft about it and almost feminine. Emphasis on the word "almost". It does manage to stay just this side of masculine. That it toes the gender line also adds to that sense of conflict.

I had sampled this in a store, was intrigued by it, but ended up purchasing something else. I got home and couldn't get Fahrenheit out of my mind and so I immediately drove half an hour back to the store in crappy weather to exchange what I had just bought for the Fahrenheit. The clerk looked at me like I was crazy. And I was. This fragrance will do that to you. It's a hard one to get off the brain for some reason.

When applied to skin, I don't detect the gasoline odor people talk about, but when I spray this on clothing, the gas vibe is noticeable and lasting. For that reason, I never spray this on clothing, only on skin.

Dec
13
2016
TonyAKAMrClean

Believe it or not, I had never smelled Fahrenheit until I purchased it blindly, but everyone told me that one of my favorites, Bora Bora Exotic, smelled just like it. Turns out, they were absolutely right! At least I have good taste in my cheapies... ;)

With that being said, I love Fahrenheit! It's strong leather with a very "red" or "warm" smelling heat about it. Much smoother than Bora Bora Exotic, but less sweet, and I must admit, I like Bora Bora Exotic's added spice notes and note separation. Still, what Fahrenheit doesn't have in spice, it makes up for with DRAMA! That fuel smell, it almost starts out like tar before dying down to just fumes... still no doubt dividing the crowd like the tar notes in A*Men.

To those who haven't smelled Fahrenheit, no, it doesn't smell like fuel from the pump. It smells like fuel where the aromachemical has worn off - in a good way, I swear! Like used motor oil, but cleaner. As in, you should feel like a well oiled machine when you wear this!

To those who are put off by the gasoline smell or those who want to experience this smell with less monetary risk and a more universally crowd pleasing aroma, I absolutely recommend Bora Bora Exotic! It only costs $14, and you will NOT be disappointed!

2016
Fragrant Desert

Fahrenheit is one of those fine fumes which seem to require taking some time to get to know. At first my experience was finding it Harsh - and yes, reminded me of working in an auto shop. Even then there was something appealing. Now am thinking how it is sort of like Dior's Poison in that you really can be caught off guard by your initial meeting. However, I know the better fragrance isn't linear and often will take time to appreciate due to it being more complex. I'd wear my Farenheit occasionally but always felt a bit unmatched .. unlike the polarizing Kouros by YSL that I came to favor as my #1 choice which was easier to mate with for me. It's a cold morning in the desert and decided to go with Fahrenheit again. TODAY it happened! Like a few others it all came together like some grand mystery. My nose, this fume and all the stars aligned so now I can Really start to perceive all the facets better in more harmony. This isn't smellinng harsh or like drilling for oil. Today this is clean (thank goodness for the light hand Dior used with the lavender.) and not at all somewhat alien, fossil fuel. This is amazing and I am beyond glad to have it right now, not for tha status or legend but because it is smelling so danm good I could wear this Anywhere. Agree to avoid spraying too high. I have learned the hard way to spray Below the chest.

01
2016
mehrdad58

I don't comment on the scent itself, but here I share a tip with you for the application of this perfume.

Do not spray this perfume around your face area and close to your nose, if you don't want to hate yourself :) This is a strong scent and you can get best results when you spray it e.g., on the wrists. Hope this helps you enjoy this scent even more...

Nov
26
2016
cfs1612

To my nose, this doesn't smell at all like a man who was just working in a garage/gasoline/the apotheosis of alpha manliness. Quite the opposite, I perceive this scent as clean and sophisticated, but yet daring and energetic, something intriguing that could be pulled off even in high class events.

Fahrenheit opens up fresh and clean. I smell a lot of lavender, but it is slowly obfuscated by the more "metallic" violet leaf. The citruses are briefly there, mostly in the immediate opening, and I can't quite distinguish between them. Leather to me is one of the major notes in the opening and in the rest of the fragrance's progression, conveying smoothness and softness, but also that masculinity that everyone talks about.

To me, Fahrenheit definitely does NOT smell like gasoline (I don't know about petroleum, as I don't recall having ever smelled the thing), although I understand why some people insist that this is the main fragrance's aspect. I think this vibe comes from the combination of leather and the many flowers listed in the pyramid, and after reading a comment mentioning chamomile, I can definitely see its contribution to this. Speaking of the flowers, as the fragrance progresses, it becomes more and more floral and woody, until it's a little sweetened in the dry down and becomes even smoother.

The ever present leather note is what I think contributes the most to keep this fragrance from being classified simply as floral, but this blend smells very complex to me (although I'm not a master in picking notes) and there's something in there that always intrigues me: I'm never sure if I like it or not, but sometimes it hits me and I'm just addicted to the stuff!

To finish this first review that I ever write, I would just also like to disagree on labeling specific types of people for specific perfumes: as long as you're CONFIDENT with yourself and reasonable about the number of sprays, you can pull anything off in any situation.

Nov
21
2016
nelsongil13

FIRE AND ICE "

" Some say the world will end in fire, Some say in ice. From what I've tasted of desire I hold with those who favor fire "...

Robert Frost

This fragrance is a masterpiece of the perfumery. Top 10 of the "Billboard of the fragrances" all the time.

It is as a mini "station of fuel", the richest of the planet, where we can supply our smell.
It is true that it does not please all people, but if you give it the opportunity, probably you will love it.

The stela is divine and the longevity very over the average.

When you wear it, you feel how people make a path for you and give you certain reverence. Let's not ruin it by using daily, this is very special.

It does not seem to any aroma that exists.

This is the most imitated, but simultaneously inimitably.

It is a fire!

Uffff. Long life to the King of the fragrances!

SheenSyke

Id always hear amazing things about this work of art but id always steer away from it since i heard this smells like gasoline n petrol which is not at all appealing.

One day i sprayed this on a test strip n i wasnt really blown away by it so i ended up buying another fragrance.

But then the next day i couldnt help but buy a bottle because even though i didnt like it. I kept thinking about it.

I opened the box and sprayed it on my wrist......this smells way different on skin than on paper and the gasoline note is there but its a pleasent one. I can smell woods and florals its deffinetly masculine and tough and i dont regret purchasing this at all. Could even be my signature scent.

remy.cullen.5

My girlfriend thought that I put on her arm something unisex, and it smelled divine! Not something I could pull off, with its strong opening and feminine drydown, but Id recommend this to any girl that has the balls to wear it, for it is something that would definitely turn my head around!

Nov
02
2016
Joemiller1961

I've used Fahrenheit since the late 80's and I can tell you that it has never really changed much at all. I've seen a few moronic people saying that it is now reformulated and as strong as the original (don't believe that BS). The reality is that it smells identical to the original (always has) and the current formula, while not nearly as rich as the OG is still good. Fahrenheit hasn't changed AT ALL since approximately the early to mid 90's.

19
2016
nehash_1

I somehow have this thing for Dior men's fragrances. And this is one of my childhood loves. One of the first fragrances that made me fall in love with perfumes. It smells so unique and sexy. And the sillage is so monstrous that people can smell it for eternity after you're gone. I can imagine that smell as I type this review and it makes me go 'yummmm'. Yes that's the word for it. My first gift to my boyfriend, now husband, was this perfume. I always wanted to wear it myself but since the smell is so distinct I always feared someone spotting me wearing a man's fragrance. Well i was quite particular about it at least when I was younger, but i may give it a try now.

As for the smell, don't know how to define it. It is quite sweet for a man's perfume, yet manly enough to make you want to get dangerously closer to him for another whiff. And closer in a sexy way, trust me you don't want your dad or your brother or the 'nice guy who you know always had a crush on you, but for you is just a friend' smelling like this.

Will always remain my most special perfume :) Now I know what to gift my hubby this Diwali!

richmilton

The nonsense of Fahrenheit returning to its original formulation in 2015-2016 is a bunch of BS! I have a November 2014 bottle and it smells just like the vintage bottle my friend has from the 90's. Some people are claiming formulations before 2015 was vanilla. Well, mine has zero vanilla, just petrol, leather and that amazing violet note. Fahrenheit is one of my all time favorites. I prefer masculine colognes and this delivers big time. There is no way a woman can pull of this fragrance. At least not any woman I know. On the right man, this is catnip for women, IME.

Yesterday I tried in the shop along with the cologne version. I even like the cologne too, they are very similar, the cologne is fresher, but you can wear all year, not only in summertime.

Sep
28
2016
miss mills

Trying this on myself for the first time now. My first love wore this, killed me then and slays me again now. He was a feisty, active and deadly cool kind of guy. Drove his grandfather's Valiant (fast), flew small planes and had a great haircut. Over the years, I've smelt weaker interpretations of this in clubs and bars on passers by and only once or twice in its original, deadly formula. This is as close as it gets to the original and omg, it is HOT. The wearer of this means business. Citrus, nutmeg, carnation, sandalwood, a twist of violet leaf and the beautiful combo of cedar and vetiver that stop this from getting anywhere near too soft and powdery, whilst still retaining that super refined mix that can turn from the fresh citrus to heated spiced passion in the blink of an eye.

I thought I would add my two cents worth to the formula discussion .I have a bottle 5N which would be Jan. Feb. 2015 .Three sprays to the torso ,gives excellent sillage and longevity, up to 10 hours with the fragrance dramatically evolving and drying down to a floral dry black leather .On clothing the scent can be detected days later .

This came in the previously mentioned black border box .Prior to this I had a much earlier bottle ,both great ,though if pressed I slightly prefer the new one .Beautiful scent ,love the opening ,intense, dark ,floral and oily ,great stuff !Thanks for reading folks .

To all fans of this legend. It's back. The new formulation is as close to the original formulation as it will ever be without it actually being vintage. I wore this several times from a perfume shop and I was blown away. Previously a few years ago I threw out a bottle, I couldn't give it away it was horrible not even close but now as I read a few reviews you must make sure you buy the bottle in the red and black box, red in the middle black on top and bottom. Sep
18
2016
Wordley

Wore this as a signature for about 3 years in th early 90's, then dropped it when it seemed to me that everyone was wearing it, and never went back. Anyhow, a couple of days ago I tried a quick spritz for old times sake while I was shopping for something else and was astonished to discover that despite some reformulation in the last 20 years that heady first blast of petrol/mineral hadn't changed one jot. It seemed to me, however, that the dry down is different now, more floral and a woodier finish - although the leather is still there. It remains a quite unique and ideosyncratic fragrance, and for that I applaud it. For sillage fans it's got to be on the list; long lasting too.

10
2016
SuzanneS

I sprayed this on my man in the department store.
At first he was overwhelmed with the petrol opening. I told him old classics like these need time to settle down. Once it did we went perfume shopping at the counter for me. The young girl helping us kept leaning over to my man and she kept playing with her blouse. Her button kept popping open, and finally she left it with part of her bra/cleavage exposed. My man looked at me and it was becoming comical. He's a rugged sort, so pretty boy-handsome ladies man isnt his bag.

She asked what he was wearing and he coldly replied "faherenheit" with a smirk and a wink as he was escorting me out the door. Once we got in the car, he looked this up on fragrantica, and said.."You were right. Its a lady killer. Apparently the vintage is better..go find me one.

03
2016
Lunchbox148

***Update***

I have just found out the new 2016 and late 2015 Fahrenheit's with the new black bordered boxes have new juice reminiscent of vintage Fahrenheit. Gone is the strong vanilla accord in the late 2012- early 2015 reformulations. This may not be news to everyone but it was to me. I went down and bought a 2015 bottle with the new redesigned box and it smelled way closer the the vintage. The petrol note stays for way longer and the fragrance has more Oomph. The sillage and longevity are the same as my 2013 bottle for what I can tell.
My obsession with finding vintages is over.

Dior is one of the only houses who listens to the cries of their loyal customers

Plus that violet note is so iconic. A man's man's cologne.

Lunchbox148

I don't know what to say, I'm speechless... my review or anyone else's would not do justice to how amazing this fragrance is. I hated it at first because it's so different- It caught me off guard...I misunderstood it. Thank God I wore it a couple more times on my skin. This fragrance smells way more complex to just say it smells like "PETROL, or GASOLINE" This fragrance is very masculine but at the same time soft and refined... My wife would prefer I wear something "fresh" and "clean".. She like's Prada Luna Rossa on me the most (lol). But this is it for me I HIGHLY doubt anything will ever impress me more. This is and will always be my signature fragrance.

Sent 12/10 the absolute definition of a fragrance masterpiece. I fell in love with Fahrenheit at it's current formulation. I have never smelled the vintage juice.

Projection 10/10 beast mode for 2 hours then still noticeable for 7 more hours minimum (10 hours+ total) with 4 sprays (2 on neck 1 on chest and 1 on under shirt) You will need to go with 4 sprays with the reformulation. I have a 2012 bottle and it has amazing longevity but it's no beast anymore but it still dose well. 4 sprays is perfect... trust me

Sillage 10/10

Longevity 10/10

Uniqueness 10/10

Modernness/Timelessness 10/10



Not meant for sissy boys

bribri121994

Any man who wears this has got my undivided attention.

Fahrenheit is one of the many reasons why I (try) to coax my man into wearing cologne. It is musky without smelling like a grandpa who liberally applies Jovan. It is woody without smelling like a wood chipper. It is smoky without smelling like cigars. Extremely pleasant, yet risky and dangerous too.

There is also an ozmotic quality in it that I just can't put my finger on. Much like ck2?

I can see this working on any man 25+, perhaps younger if accompanied with the right attitude.

2016
nonsisa

My first reaction for this one was rather gross and obscene.

Nevertheless I somehow managed to like it and really got hooked on this classic. That was back in the 90's.

However two years ago I haunted down an old bottle from the first production series; the one with the yellow bottomed box.
I was happy for having found that old gem and proud to wear this specialty. That changed quickly after a few wears that were so headache inducing that I voluntarily gave up wearing it. Needless to say that I had to sell off the bottle.

From what I've experienced I would advise to stay away from the vintage formulation, as it might be a little bit to hard and could fuck up your brain nerves.

Having said all that it still will remain one of the manliest and best leather scents ever produced!

2016
sproaty

Man oh man do I love this. I've undergone a very strange journey with Fahrenheit - I remember my first spray a few months ago and really disliking it initially, but then doing a total 180 on that and loving it during its drydown. I really smelled that burnt, fuel vibe that this is so known for. Nowadays though...I get a massive flower bomb basically - lots of orange up the top too which I never noticed during my first 12 or so wears! That burnt vibe has also become a lot harder to detect. It's beautiful, it's complex and I'm still always intrigued by it.

Absolutely one of my favourite scents.

Scent: 10/10
Projection: 8/10
Longevity: 8/10

velgasius

It lasts a long time but very transparent. If you smelt this on someone you won't think he was using perfume, he would seem like he did some hard labour that would give him that manly smell (like fixing his motorcycle or mowing his lawn) while still having that clean & fresh out of the shower smell lingering about. Like he did a bit of work but not too much that it makes him smell bad. Unfortunately the projection is just about average, but some claim it performs better in the heat!

Jul
27
2016
iwhiffwaft

Thinking on this fragrance. Yeah, I don't really know why someone would make this, but I'm a regular dude. I was a Crewchief in the Air Force, so I worked on plane's and got greasy and dirty with a bunch of other guys. Manly job, for manly men. I can't think of any one of us who thought we'd actually like to smell the way we smelled after getting drenched in JP-8 fuel, or lube oil. Nope, no one of the "real" men I ever knew ever thought of anything but it stank and you had to wash that crap off.

So, there's another side of my personality and mind that visualizes some artsy dude somewhere going, "Yes, if we want to make a manly smell, let's create oil/gas smell"?. All us stanky sweaty gas smelling dude's were probably all sexy as hell to folks who never pounded a hammer or used a wrench.

So, masculinity is smelling like I just got pooped on by JP-8 aircraft fuel. LOL........

I actually like the whole fragrance though. It's velvety and nice. The petrol note isn't the entirety of the fragrance and its really a good all around fragrance. It just makes me ponder all the things I don't know about how some people think on masculinity, and I find it a bit funny.

Jul
26
2016
farook

I have worn this fragrance since mid-nineties when the bottle cap was still plastic-reformulation has definitely affected its longevity and projection since the mid2000 onwards. The current bottle I own will probably be the last Farenheit I own as I keep comparing it to the superior quality it once had while the current one falls short. It becomes a skin scent after 3hrs, when the old one projected strongly even after 6hrs. Thanks for the memories CD, Farenheit will always have a special place in my heart, that's why I don't wish to get another bottle because it's a letdown these days.

Jul
25
2016
no-fi

Fahrenheit is Ballard in a bottle; it is post-modernity captured in fittingly fleeting fragrant molecules.

I was not expecting to feel such a strong, instant attraction to this scent. Fahrenheit's reputation is so fierce, and its audience so divided, that I was equivocal about whether to even try it.

I'm glad I finally took the plunge. This juice is fantastic - it makes me feel the same way I did the first time I tried Bvlgari Aqva. The two scents are completely different, but there is something so dirty and yet so fresh about both. While the dirtiness in Aqva is all about the seaweed and salt, the dirtiness in Fahrenheit is a much more bracing discord of grease and leather.

And oh, what a leather! It's one of the best I've smelled. It works so well with the violet leaf - a note I usually dislike. There's a real industrial-pastoral contrast at play here.

Forget about the talk of Fahrenheit's masculinity, or the gasoline accord, or reformulations. The real narrative here is allegorical - think of Fahrenheit less as a fragrance, and more as a work of science fiction art. This is the scent of the post-apocalypse. What a masterpiece.

Jul
22
2016
Carlos is an icon

Hello my friend! Remember the late 80s the longer your on my body and cloths the better you smell. Masterpiece!

Jul
15
2016
Sahmad

Dior's masterpiece. My all time favourite.

Jul
14
2016
Blanc'd

This isn't a review actually. It's more of an interesting note I read regarding the infamous "petroleum" note found in Fahrenheit.

It comes from this young lady:

Author: Marina Milojevi (Mary)
Fragrantica Writer, Translator & Editor

It reads:

"One of the perfumes where chamomile note dominates the composition is certainly Diors iconicFahrenheit for men. Launched in late eighties, this deep and masculine fragrance still captivates our attention, spreading the heady soul of chamomile right from the top notes. Chamomile note lends to this fragrance its distinctive petroleum hint, which can be felt in the very opening. In this calming and manly interpretation, chamomile is combined with soothing scent of lavender, a hint of lemon, and some deep and sensual nuances of wood and musk."

I always thought the gasoline note was attributed to the violet leaf/jasmine/vetiver combo- not Chamomile. This is quite surprising to me.

Anyway, I thought this might be helpful when reading about this iconic fragrance. If it spurs debate among members who thought they were certain of what caused that infamous accord I can't see the harm in that.

Thanks for reading!

Jun
28
2016
joenick68

Jun
23
2016
Micelle

Stridently masculine, and definitely greater than the sum of its parts.

The opening reminds me of asphalt and hot copper, with individual notes almost indistinguishable, but after forty minutes or so the anatomy of the scent starts to show. The heart this fragrance is humble mid-weight florals: chamomile, violet, lavender and honeysuckle (or their synthetic doppelgangers) somehow alchemize with leather notes to create something else entirely. After two hours or so, the florals die off, and you end up with spicy warmth, plus a little something extra which I can't identify that keeps it mysterious.

Not for everyone, and certainly not for all women. I wear this fragrance because I'm a lesbian, but extremely feminine-looking. Fahrenheit's hypermasculinity is my way of hinting that all is not as it appears.

Jun
09
2016
fabio.bernieri

Grande classico. Adoro la sferzata di benzina iniziale. Sulla mia pelle purtroppo non particolarmente intenso n particolarmente persistente.

Voto personale: 7.5/10

Jun
09
2016
Konga5000

********* A RED HOT FIREPLACE POKER of a FRAG!*****************

Discovered this late in the game but I'm glad that I did now!

This is a staple in my growing-too-large frag collection (that if I had to whittle it down to 3 frags only--this would be one of them!)
Such a distinctive scent..... powerful even in current (presumably "watered down") versions. Please don't fret over this -- (especially if you have not bought & tried it yet!) This stuff is strong and long lasting -- so you really get your value with this.
But that scent ... what is it.....
Motor oil? No.
Gasoline? No.

What this in fact smells like is the hand de-greasing compound than comes in a round tin; used by mechanics and such (big macho me; I remember it from junior high school shop class however).
Forgive me -- I forget the brand name!

This is NOT FOR EVERYONE. Do not blind buy. And I say that with love.

Unforgettable , unique and devilishly vulgar!
-------------------------------------------
Side note about the older formulation:
Scored a 20 year old bottle a few weeks ago in a thrift store. The leather is amped up in the older version, but that's about it. I guess?
-------
Available at Target no less!

Jun
08
2016
nitschevo

Oh. My. God.
A colleague of mine wears this today and our office is in love right now. This is gorgeous! I would very happily follow any lad who smells like this. No candy necessary. The initial impression is green and bright, it reminds me of Charles Revson Ultima II. No gasoline or anything reminiscent of that smell detectable. Only swoon worthy fresh smell with a punch that reminds me of more classic colognes. Apologies for the rambling and not quite helpful review really BUT if you haven't tried it, get on your feet now.

2016
NX1011

While perhaps brash and overtly masculine- this fragrance is quite simply splendid. All of the lavish superlatives are accurate; you would be remiss to overlook this fragrance.

Worth noting that upon sampling the current formulation, I immediately noticed that the note of violet leaf had been toned down quite a bit. I applaud that decision as I believe Fahrenheit is now considerably more versatile and agreeable as a result.

Scent: 9/10
Projection: 10/10
Longevity: 8/10

Jun
06
2016
rodofiron312

This is how a Mechanical Engineer should smell like. This fragrance smells like engine. The gasoline vibe is definitely there. Some of the familiar notes I notice were leather, lavender and patchouli. Preferably, I don't like patchouli but in this fragrance it's barely noticeable therefore it's acceptable. The floral notes come out during drydown. I can say this fragrance is very masculine. It's unique. Doesn't smell like any other fragrances I came across with. Also, it projects well and lasts long. I consider this as a daring scent though. Everyone will not love it. But it doesn't matter 'cause when I wear this one, it makes me confident.

Rating:

Scent-8/10
Longevity-10/10
Projection-10/10

Jun
03
2016
Luna_J

I just found a 2003 bottle of this and, though obviously reformulations can be something one overthinks, was immediately transported back to the summer I was nineteen (1990)... This is not an experience I have had with the most recent formulation (black framed box), which I actually had to return owing to an allergic reaction.

Though the 1980's-90's formulation remains my favourite to date (the florals there were very wonderful), this 2003 batch has a rich violet-leather petroleum accord that does not smell thin or acrid at all. I'm really reminded of the designation 'woody floral musk' here, as the musk base feels denser and more oleos, adding a nice counterpoint to the fougere-like fresh-sour aspects of the floral notes. The leather in the 2003 version smells more oily and comforting than the rather edgy and pronounced, 'shoe polish' quality of the 2014 batch I tried several months ago. There are some wonderful notes clearly discernible underneath (lavender, vetiver, nutmeg, cedar, chamomile), underscoring for me the original mystery of this fragrance that gets lost in so many of the polarized reviews with their debates about "masculinity": Fahrenheit was and should be a deeply abstracted, 'industrial' accord that gives way to a comforting ('worn-in') interplay naturalistic notes -- wildflowers sprouting between post-apocalyptic ruins, retrofuturist but Romantic. Without that contradiction (a synthetic impression rendered by naturals, rather than vice-versa), there's no beauty to flesh out the concept.

I'm frankly surprised at its note separation, staying power and how pleasantly it projects. The musky-honeysuckle drydown is especially lovely. Fahrenheit always reminded me of summer on the road with my best friend and it is wonderful to have those sensations again.

May
28
2016
Dave5807

I've been wearing this since it was sprayed in my face at a dept store back in the 80's. I've seen it go through changes, but it remains a timeless treasure and a big part of my collection.

The only downside is that Fahrenheit just doesn't last. That has been the case from the 80's, 90's and 00's bottles I've owned.

I never get compliments unless I have just sprayed it. It literally has to be within the hour or I get no compliments. Rarely will I catch a wiff of this after the 3-4 hour mark.

I'm not going to go crazy into the review. By now we have all tried it and know if we like it or not.

I still give this a 7/10 but it would be perfect if it lasted.

I will also say that I have never smelled this on anyone before. Obviously a lot people wear it. That just further testifies my statement about the poor longevity. Oh well, it is still a favorite of mine. I just keep a little tester to reapply every 3 hours.

May
28
2016
Yellow club

I was looking forward to getting this fragrance for a while and I finally got a sample yesterday. WoW! I was quite surprised with my reaction actually; I did not like it at all.

I have heard great reviews about this fragrance and people love it but on my skin it gives off an interesting aroma. When I first spray it, I get some citrus and floral note which are actually really good but the dry-down smells like petroleum, car oil fluid. It reminded me of an old car repair shop and that took me by surprise!

I can definitely see what they were going for because I like some of the opening notes but I just cannot get pass the petroleum/car oil smell. I am quite disappointed because I like Dior fragrances and I was looking forward to enjoy this one. I am glad that I did not do a "blind buy" of this fragrance because I would throw it away. So, I recommend that you try this fragrance on your skin before you buy it because the smell may take you by "surprise".

In all, this fragrance just makes me feel resentful and it's weird! I just can't figure out why it brings up feelings of resentment; maybe it's because in my mind I was expecting some fantastic fragrance that I would enjoy but that was a complete 180 degrees for me.

mhiregoudar

My favorite fragrance of all time, FAHRENHEIT...
2014 Formulation..

In the opening of this fragrance i get a mixture of used 85-W-90 Grade gear oil + used 68 grade hydraulic oil + green paste from leaves, poured onto a leather seat....

After an hour's mark, all i get is a freshly polished leather shoes, where the smell of pure leather is prominent with a hint of shoe polish.

After 4 hours, all I am left up with is a Green Woody, leather & musk combo.

Really love the way it changes as the day progresses, never got a compliment though. I wear it for myself. Never get bored of it.

Longevity: 10+ hours easily
Projection: Average

10/10

Apr
03
2016
NZFH

Somehow I have lived on this planet since the 1970s and have not previously smelt this scent (or cannot remember doing so).

All I get from the opening is petroleum/gasoline. A bit later, a greasy lawnmower or mowing shed. After that, a leathery soapy vibe mixed with engine-oil grease.

I don't get any citrus, freshness, or woods. No way. Just smells greasy, leathery, soapy on me, like petroleum jelly mixed with a very spicy leathery masculine soap.

The metaphor of a mechanic leaving the workshop, then showering with soap, is what comes to mind (as one reviewer said elsewhere). Oh, except maybe mowing the lawn in between the workshop and the shower.

People complaining about the reformulation getting rid of the petrol/gasoline vibe, are you serious? If this was any more petrolly, I don't think I would want to wear it. Also, I would be worried about catching fire.

And btw I don't get any of the supposed new vanilla note.

This is a hyper-masculine smell and I don't have anything else in my collection like this. It is SO different and unusual, and atypical for me I like it!

Apr
01
2016
miracleborgtech

I haven't smelled this in years, but read some fantastic reviews and ordered samples of vintage Fahrenheit. Great positive associations from the past. I remember this from clubbing, and it is incredible! Wish more men wore it today. It is a unique intense fragrance, and perfect for nightime activities. It projects confidence and style. Don't know where these references to mechanics, etc. are coming from, because this is more a scent for upscale suit clad movers and shakers. It's fun and flirty. Strong sillage and longevity - less is more!

Mar
27
2016
micp

After many years without, I recently purchased a small vintage vial of Fahrenheit off of ebay man, I'd forgotten just how heady this stuff is! I've still never experienced anything quite like it.

After wearing it straight yesterday, I thought it might go well layered with a generic ISO E Super, and I really like the result. In fact, when first applied, it's so intense that I almost got a bit nauseous but in a good way! I completely understand that some people are put off by the petrol element in Fahrenheit, but it just works for me not everyday, but when the mood strikes. I also like that it's almost a polar opposite of my favorite scent , Annick Goutal's Sables.

I'd also say that Fahrenheit is, perhaps more than any other I've ever used, a CITY scent. Scents are often classified by seasons, or times of day, but I think locale is every bit as significant as those. Cities are loud, busy, gritty places, and Dior's Fahrenheit fits in the urban landscape like few others.

Mar
20
2016
micavana

My bottle of Fahrenheit is from 2010, so it is before the reformulation that added a vanilla type note. Don;t get me wrong I love vanilla, but in the case of Fahrenheit, that does not work for me. While i appreciate Vanilla in other fragrances, Fahrenheit is / should be all about the masculine gasoline, wood and leather vibe.

To be honest. I bought this several years and and I didn't like this fragrance the first time I tried it. A very heavy scent. It can be a bit overpowering. But over time I grew to love it. It is very complex scent that I did not appreciate at the time. Now that my nose has developed a bit more., I am so glad I held on to it. A great sent IMO.

Bottom line, try a sample of this one and see how it works on your skin. But you may need to try it a few times.

Mar
19
2016
mehrdad








Mar
18
2016
Germany

I find the smell of Fahrenheit fascinating ! It's not your every day cologne , that's for sure , Fahrenheit does not smell like cologne but like "atmosphere." Like an outdoorsy smell of something maybe burning in the far distance. Petroleum , oil , gasoline ,,,, a burnt tire ? It's just so peculiar , which makes it so interesting and unique.
Right in the beginning its a dense , full bodied , a nose full of ozonic oil , meaning somewhere in the atmosphere and not right under your nose. The feel of something !
Next stage I get more leather or suede still with some gasoline , very masculine and sexy in my opinion.

Then there is a spice that's rarely used in perfumes , nutmeg . I use a lot of nutmeg in the kitchen , it's one of my staples for spicing cauliflower and mashed potatoes. It's a familiar smell. I love it.
Again a sexy rugged man comes to mind.
Another note creeps up which is indeed my favourite note in perfumes , and it's violets , it's a bit of an old school smell , a classic , lipstick feel , but here it's imbedded in oils and nutmeg and suede Leather , ,,,,fantastic , genius.
No wonder this perfume stood the test of time. It's truly different. Does not smell mainstream at all , and as masculine as its intended to be I find it fantastic as a unisex perfume and love it on myself also. It's certainly not feminine by no measure but it's such a neat smell , not a perfume nor cologne smell.
This middle stage is soft leather and Violet's still with an oily undertone.
Would it be right to say this is a highly sexual scent ? Smells of sex ?
As odd and unusual as the beginning may be , it does get to the point were the smell becomes even better and liked by all. It takes a while but once it is at that stage it's highly enjoyable and much less peculiar as the gasoline oily beginning .
In the end stage it's fresh on me. Just a really good fresh smell. Warm fresh , vetevier .... Addictive.

Mar
15
2016
kwh

I adore the vintage version of Fahrenheit, not so much the reformulation. I never got gasoline or oil from this fragrance, although I am one of those odd people who enjoys the smell of things like gasoline and oil so maybe I just didn't notice. For me Fahrenheit was a delicious blend of some of my favorite notes: leather, amber, vetiver, cedar, lavender, spice, and citrus. I always thought of it as a unisex scent, but again, I guess I'm an odd person who doesn't care whether a fragrance is "supposed" to be for a man or a woman. I just wear what I like. This review is only about the vintage fragrance. I dislike the reformulated version so much that I don't even consider it to be the same thing.

Mar
15
2016
gelo999

Fahrenheit is perhaps one of the aromas with more personality in worldwide designer fragrances and an iconic piece in the maison Dior has already become a classic.

Its originality when it was released and caused a lot of impact is so peculiar that today remains a different bet due to the characteristic scent of aromatic leather effect similar to gasoline. This effect is due to a combination of lavender brings a fougere effect, spicy notes like nutmeg, violet leaves and woods like vetiver, cedar, of course a great deal of leather and finishing drying use of musks that provide an expansive look with very good wake.

I still have a vintage bottle with all the powerful aroma that was when it was released this wonder and treasured.

Rating: 8
