Feb
28
2016
jackmonaghan

I tested this for the first time today and, as much as I enjoy "different" fragrances, I really didn't like this at all. I suppose I should have expected it with a name like "Fahrenheit", but I wasn't prepared for how overwhelmingly this would smell of...burnt. To me it just smells like a bonfire, but not a pleasant, hot cocoa and marshmallows kind of bonfire. More like a petrol-drenched bonfire that's been set in some woods by a group of drunk teenagers who threw aerosols into it before letting it burn out on its own. Fahrenheit smells of that bonfire 3 days after it went out; a musty, smoky, smell of ash that burns your nostrils. Not at all pleasant. And yes, I did spray it on my skin and let it dry-still not much better.

All in all, hats off to Dior for thinking outside the box, but not a good fragrance for me.

4/10

Feb
28
2016
VVHYY

Dior Fahrenheit was a watershed fragrance. In my teenage years I wore fragrances that were gifted to me. In my 20s I got a bit curious, reading about fragrances online and happened upon Grey Flannel as a cheap option that I found I liked well enough. In my 30s my wife and I had popped into a Sephora and, on a whim, spent an afternoon sniffing test strips. One fragrance was a bit strange. Smell this! What is that? It smells like your shirt after mowing the lawn. Is that bad? I always kind of liked the smell of gasoline. What do you think? Im just going to spray a little bit on my arm.

And that was that.

Ive never shook that association of a heady mix of small engine exhaust and fresh cut grass. Fahrenheit radiates off the body as a fume. You can almost see light dancing and refracting around it like summer blacktop. This is what makes it so pleasing to wear. It evokes heat and scorched expanses, leather jackets and spilled gasoline, crushed green leaves and garages. It doesn't smells like you sprayed something on, it smells like you did something.

I wore the current formulation for years and just recently had the pleasure of obtaining some vintage. While the vintage I have has a bit stronger fuel smell its not enough of a contrast to lament the current formulation. If theres a stronger version Im game. But I wouldnt hesitate to recommend it as is. A must have.

24
2016

jsb41

Seriously, when I selling cologne, I hated this stuff. Actually thought a little motor oil on you chest would have the same effect. Nope. Not even close. Here's the thing though, go easy on this stuff, very easy and for God's sake, let a cologne develop on your skin before you go off screeching and reaching for that ol' safe Aqua Di Gio. This cologne to me is the olfactory equivalent that says, "I got this, no worries. Now get out of my way and let me work." Will some still hate It? Sure, but please don't write it off on your first spray. People are in such a big hurry these days. Fragrances have to develop. As for me? You come around me smelling like this much man and you just may send my estrogen receptors into overdrive-in the best possible way.

Feb
04
2016
citizenoftriton

Description: Imagine yourself coming back inside after having mown the lawn, your smooth leather jacket giving off an aroma of fresh-cut grass, hay and wild flowers with a hint of lawnmower fumes.

Recommendation: Much more versatile than it is reputed to be, Fahrenheit works well in all weather except sweltering heat and can be worn for leisure, formal events and nights out.

Creativity*: 5
Blend**: 4.5
Distinctiveness***: 4
Performance: 4.25
Mass appeal: 3.5
Allure****: 3.75
Design: 4.5
Name: 5

Personal appreciation: 4.25 out of 5

Final notes: A timeless classic that smells ahead of its time even in 2016. In my experience, not nearly as polarizing as some make it out to be. A complex scent composed of green, floral, leathery and woody notes.

-----
*Creativity: A frag gets a perfect score if it was the first of its kind on the market and if this kind was a game changer; **Blend: A perfect blend will trigger your imagination, take you places, but won't try to be the exact copy of something that exists in the world (in other words, single-themed gourmands get low scores); ***Distinctiveness: If everybody is wearing it and/or there are uncounted olfactory twins on the market: low score; ****Allure: Assessment based on verbal and non-verbal reactions from my surroundings.

Jan
15
2016
louisevonteese

I bought this for my man after reading great reviews. I wanted a mature, professional and manly smell for my man and I knew I was onto a winner when I bought this.

My man wanted a different fragance to the ones he uses which are, in my opinion, nice but not enough of the Wow factor.

I have smelt this on other men and other women - gay women to be precise - and I love it. It is unique, warm, spicey and then a hint of leather which is dark and broody and that excites me. However, when my man tried this, it just smelt like cold, harsh leather, no warmth and no spice. Like an old leather jacket that has been left in the rain to rot. Not pleasent. He was disappointed. I was disappointed. Even my mother was disappointed as this was the fragnance she bought my dad when it came out but she claimed that 'This is not the same!"

In conclusion, I cannot have my man smelling like an old, cold leather jacket. It may be his skin which makes it cold and harsh but as I cannot change my man's skin to the skin of other men where this smells divine, it is the fragnance that needs to be changed.

If you live in the UK and this fragrance does not make you smell like a cold leather jacket, I have a 50ml bottle, sprayed 5 times that I would like to go to a new home.

Jan
02
2015
Lightning

Vintage Fahrenheit was one of my favorites. It had a smooth, grassy, violet-honey aroma with a small hint of gasoline.

The modern reformulation (since 2012) is more like a strong punch of leather with a little of the elements I described above. Still good, but got knocked down a few pegs.

Even though I respect it a lot, I personally don't wear this one often because everyone has smelled it and everyone knows what it is. I sort of want a cologne that I can carve my own identity into, if that makes sense.

Projection and longevity are very good. Wearable for all seasons, but spray carefully during summer. Well-made fragrance with quality ingredients.

Rating: ***** (Vintage) , **** (Current)

Dec
30
2015
jacked 24/7

First ill start by saying I am no perfume cologne expert. So if you haven't smelled this scent yet this is my opinion on it.. Imagine yourself eating an orange, making a mess of it and smearing the peels on yourself. Then going to pump gas and letting it drench all over your arms.. Giving no f***. Then heading to throw on your lumberjack clothes to chop some wood. All this while wearing leather wrist guards. This stuff punches you in the face. After buying it I made the mistake of using 5 sprays on myself and fair warning, this could make you quite nauseous as it did to me. But I do like the scent, as long as you go easy on the trigger. It screams masculine which is something rare these days. Btw if you disagree with my review, I own the newest reformulation and have never smelled the other ones. I do recommend trying before buying! But you were warned, you may end up on the discovery channel after using this.
8.8/10
Longevity: 9/10
Sillage: 9/10
Scent: 8.5/10

Dec
30
2015
PercivalGoldstone

Smells incredible but the performance of the current formulation is a bummer -- way too subtle. It didn't give me enough umph to achieve satisfaction. I think it should be more robust.

How amazing this must have been before reformulations; it's depressing to think something so good is gone forever.

Oh well. Best enjoyed after showering with pine tar soap.

Dec
27
2015
BlueBuddha

This has been my summer daily driver since the moment it hit the shelves almost 30 years ago, although I'm surprised to see most reviewers do not consider this a summer scent. Perhaps it's the honeysuckle & jasmine, but I've always considered this my warm weather go-to.

Over the years, I've had far more inquiries and compliments - both male & female - about this great fragrance than any other I've worn.

Go easy though, guys. Fahrenheit projects like mad and has serious staying power.

Dec
26
2015
wolflarson

This has been one of my most complimented fragrances of the past year. I believe it will continue to become my signature. I am a young man under the age of 25, so that may influence this review.

I have the most recent formulation, but to me it is still strong. I am almost "addicted" to this, like some people are to the smell of gasoline. This has led to serial resprays, just to repeat that amazing opening.

It is a great blend of violet, mandarin,honeysuckle, vetiver,sandalwood and MOST importantly, LEATHER.

It smells both decadent and carefree. Its tone seems to be of that which cannot be held down. Carefree and masculine.

In times when "mens" fragrances smell more like womens perfumes ( I am looking at you Dior Homme), I am glad to have this stuff around.

It lasts on my very dry skin for about 5 hrs.I spray my clothes to get longer use. Its projection seems faint after four hours, but I swear I've been complimented on this more when it was past five hrs since the application. This is surprising, since I myself would only get whiffs of it at that point.
I have worn it year round, and it always seems to adjust to the temperature.

I think that the leather in this is AS GOOD as Tuscan Leather.

Fahrenheit leather is a great mix of supple glove leather and a broken-in baseball glove. Tuscan Leather smells like an old, stately, never been sat in leather couch. Both are good in their own way, but Fahrenheit has this "lived-in" quality that seems to create the feeling that I need to become as adventurous and storied as the fragrance I am sporting.

I love Fahrenheit, and maybe you will as well.

Dec
26
2015
Godinezmarco

I will never be without a bottle of this juice. One of the best scents ever made. Such a classy and sexy aroma .

JWR

If you don't like this, you are not a man.

2015
Guinea54

Here is an idea for you those who applaud when fragrances get watered down.... Use less sprays???? I have a vintage A*men.. Its strong as shit.. So that means i can use one quick spray and be set all day.. And people can still actually smell me.

Fahrenheit is a masterpiece. It isn't dated.. Its a timeless fragrance meant for men, not sissies. I have gotten a shit load of compliments from this fragrance my entire life. It has character, and there is way more to it than just a "dirty Oil" smell. the leather/petroleum smell is the rich and masculine base which the violet and mandarin sit on top. This scent is dirty and rich, yet clean and soapy, and sometimes even fresh smelling. I am almost out of my bottle and I am afraid at what they might have done to the newest formulation of this stuff.. They probably watered it down even more and made it more into wimp juice for the delicate , easily offended girly men out there now. But these guys have no problems wearing sugar bombs like one million that are nauseatingly sweet. They even had to F#$k up fahrenheit parfum and totally destroy the heart and dna of fahrenheit. Well .. in a society where women are encouraged to be men, and men to be women.. and everything turned upside its head.. really... what chance does a classic masculine fragrance have in this world.. RIP fahrenheit.. You are too good for 2015.

renzo77

this is the best but feel the intensity applied 10 times last time I take 12 and felt a whole morning the smell

Dec
04
2015
DryDownTown

An absolute gem, one of my favourites. Truly unique. You have to smell it to believe it.

To my untrained nose, I can only really describe the opening as smelling like you have doused yourself in Creosote (the stuff people used to paint their garden fences with back in the day). It's almost a mixture of petrol and fresh tar. You smell like you've been working on a car all day, like a proper bloke. Like you should be wearing a leather jacket.

Then it dries down into an amazing leathery, soapy scent that is unique and pleasant but not overbearing. It's how you wish all Leather scents smelt.

I get a lot of compliments when I wear Fahrenheit, both from the younger and the more mature ladies. It's a big hit.

The petrol scent projects a lot so I'd recommend spraying on a while before leaving the house. The scent itself will last all day and gently lingers. People only smell the drydown if they get within talking distance.

I easily get 12+ hours out of it and can smell it on my jacket for days.

Subtle fragrances are the in thing for the modern man. It's there but only when a person is within an arm's length or kissing distance from you. Cheers.

11
2015
Maxvonembs

This is a review for a vintage bottle: 2M01 from 12/2002 and not 12/2012. I must say the 2002 version which is still in the old style bottle packs the exact same punch that my 1989 bottle has. The 2002 -2003 versions remain untested by the Raiders of the Lost Scent crew.

The initial hit from spraying the 2002 EDT is what I would call a grassy petroleum fog and it is quite strong; my spouse can easily detect this on me all day and she cannot be in the room with me when I scent up with this vile beast. She does not care for this fragrance; I adore it so I wear it. The long term dry down with the EDT is very mossy to my nose and awesome. I can smell it on my shirts for over a week. Amazingly I can iron a freshly washed shirt and the smell of vintage Fahrenheit will be strong!

This fragrance does not smell dated at all to me. Next to most of todays wimpy offerings it is wonderful and even surprises people as somewhat exotic.

The closest you can currently get to this is Fahrenheit Absolute and IMO it vanishes like sweet candy in an hour or so. Although it does last fairly well on clothing and hair.

Although they smell completely different, vintage Fahrenheit is just as good as my vintage M7 and I like it just as much.

10/10

2015
DSun

So I finally got my hands on a vintage version (the one with 30, avenue hoche address) wishing that I would like it because of all the rave reviews from just about everywhere. Beforehand, I had the reformulation but found the petrol note too overpowering. But even with the vintage, it's still a no dice. I still don't like it. It smells like I'm filling up my fuel tank in a flower shop. Or wearing a leather jacket arrested in the midst of the tanning process. The imagery is just incongruous and surreal.

Truth be told, I even prefer the reformulated version just because it's more floral, sweeter, more accessible.

And speaking of surreal, you might want to try Salvador Dali pour homme if you like that petrol note used sparingly but to great effect. It was made by a pre-Guerlain Thierry Wasser still in his 20's but already at the top of his game.

Its more similar to the Parfum version. Its not that the fragrance is entirely sweet, but you can now detect sweeter floral notes along with the petrol. I have two vintage bottles from 1987. If one were to smell the new and the old side by side they would never guess that they are the same fragrance.

mikenac

It is with great sadness that I write this review as this was one of my favorite scents in the 90's. I know that noses can change and skin chemistry can change, so I won't go on about reformulation.

What I can say is that I do not get the brilliant warm, inviting, daring scent I remember from the early 90's. At first spritz I got an echo of the florals that made the opening so magical. Sadly, these faded in seconds, and gave way to an intense gasoline smell.

Maybe my recollection is faulty, but I believe there used to more florals to balance the gasoline overtones. I can detect the old juice in there somewhere, but this balance was what made this scent a masterpiece.

For whatever reason, this is just not for me any more :(

Oct
23
2015
Luna_J

This review is for the most recent reformulation, 2014 batch code [the new box with a black border.]

After wearing Fahrenheit in my late teens/early 20s (early 1990s), I was a bit circumspect about revisiting it, having read articles and reviews about the IFRA bans and reformulations. The tester I tried in the store (an earlier 2012 or 13? - batch and box design) was different than my memories of the vintage version: less floral/honeysuckle as a continuum to move through the cut grass violet leaf and into the nutmeg/petrol/leather transitions, but still quite strong and affecting. Notably, the leather was deeper and richer, more luxury car interior, and with less of a woody (cedar/sandalwood) base than the old stuff. Different, certainly, but attractive and potentially addictive; worth purchasing, I thought.

Sadly, the newest formulation (black-border box) was very short lived on me, lasting on average about 4-5 hours before more or less disintegrating. Why make a leather that starts off strong only to fade so quickly? For context, I like to wear things with discrete projection Eau Sauvage or Carons Pour Un Homme- and apply fairly liberally. I dont mind EDC-strength fragrances, and appreciate a lingering skin scent for the intimacy it provides.

Back to the perfume: in the newest formulation I purchased, there is even less of a floral richness than in previous years, leaving the gasoline note more exposed and unsupported. The leather is now more sharply aniline (ammoniac), so that the overall bandaid note many have discerned in Fahrenheit is more noticeable. This can be OK (it is a bit habit-forming, that bandaid), but the overall body of the composition is just not supporting this idiosyncratic note in a rich enough way to make the experience pleasurable over time. The saddest news for me personally was that this current incarnation of Fahrenheit gave me headaches and a lingering sore throat (cant figure this out lyral can be an issue, and I may have just developed a sensitivity over the years, but I used to bathe in this as a teenager and theres less lyral than ever in this since the IFRA restrictions).

This is especially sad to me because the topnotes still excite as Fahrenheit, and I still find myself haunted by the scents (now mostly excavated and approximated) olfactory profile. There is a kind of perfume exhaustion unique to reformulations like this, where you keep longing for an experience that is sketched out (like the foundation of a ruined building) but no longer present. Can the nose experience phantom limb syndrome?

As someone who actually likes Francois Demachy's current reformulation of Eau Sauvage (for my money, better than the 2003-09 batch), I was really shocked at the gutting of the new Fahrenheit. I think it's important to try to find things one likes in the current market, and generally am mistrustful of the position that any vintage is necessarily always better than what's available now. I even accept the notion that tastes change and older iterations of genres like the fougere must be updated and reassessed, but this just feels like mercenary cost-cutting and a general disrespect for one's customer base.

So, in summary Without the compositional cohesion provided by a richer (read: higher quality) materials, Fahrenheit is now a string of reminders of itself without meaningful continuity, provoking the kind of knee-jerk emotional responses of a relationship in which affection has departed leaving only the old residual longings, pangs and tensions. Everything left that's good just breeds resentment.

Oct

Mme si je m y connaissais pas trop...
Bref. le prendre sans hsiter

I also smelled this abroad in a legit store and did a comparison with Fahrenheit 32 in hotter weather, and it got outdone on performance. I always considered F32 weaker. I prefer designer scents for several reasons but the reformulations are just too much to keep track of, are niche fragances more reliable? I am starting to wonder.

2015
rebeccajay

This is one of the sexiest, most masculine scents I have ever had the pleasure to enjoy. I first smelled this on my husband back when we first met in 1991. At the tender age of 19, I had never been so stunned by a man or his scent before and fell hard. We were married within 6 months and have been married 24 years now. He doesn't wear Fahrenheit every day, but when he does, it takes me right back to those heady days of new love. He used to travel for work and while he was gone I would douse his pillow with this scent and cuddle with it. Every once in a while when I'm feeling nostalgic, I will open his bottle and close my eyes, inhale, and reminisce.

I have smelled a lot of men's colognes over the years, trying to find him new scents for gifts- he smells incredible in Hermes Poivre Samarcande, Bell'Antonio, A*Men, Grey Flannel, 1902 Eau de Cologne The Vert, YSL L'Homme, Prada Luna Rossa, and others...but nothing makes me weak in the knees like Fahrenheit. A true masterpiece. Bravo!

Oct
06
2015
mhobba

Fahrenheit isn't something one can fully appreciate with one sniff. It certainly isn't something that should be dismissed after one sniff either. Unlike other fougeres of the same period, there is no urinal cake or body odour vibe to speak of. Fahrenheit was entirely unique within it's own era and still remains so today.

While I haven't been lucky enough to smell a vintage bottle, I am so happy with my 200ml bottle from 2014. Between its inception and today, ingredients will have changed. but performance for me isn't short of fantastic. Those who feel otherwise may need to consider whether they have become overloaded and fatigued by this scent. On certain days, I have noticed it does have a tendency to seemingly fade out and then pop up again throughout the day.

As for the smell of this fragrance, I get a lot of the floral elements up front. There is the unmistakably relaxing scent of freshly brewed chamomile tea which mixes with cologne classic lavender and sweet mandarin which gives some the idea of that much fabled petroleum note. This does not smell like fuel though. It isn't at all nauseating or headache inducing.

As the scent warms up on your skin, you feel the spicy presence of freshly grated nutmeg and clove like carnation with the clean white combination of jasmine, lily-of-the-valley and honeysuckle amplified by monochromatic violet leaf. It is at this point where the woody dryness begins to make itself known, but remaining firmly on the backbench.

I wouldn't say Fahrenheit is even slightly sweet overall. but by the time the base notes head centre stage, you predominantly smell heavy, worn in leather, with an earthy mixture of vetiver, patchouli and musk that is sweetened over so mildly with tonka and amber. They are subtle, but amping them up any more would be far too feminine for Fahrenheit.

Fahrenheit is such a joy to experience and makes even me feel macho enough to take on a pack of lions. I don't feel this is dated, especially compared to its peers. A true masterpiece..

Oct
05
2015
ncottrell87

Longetivity: 100/10 yes one hundred. Lasting 10+ hours with 1 spray
Projection: 9.99/10
Fragrance 10000/10

NicheMaster29

Like most of diors masterpieces they take some time to wear them and appreciate them to really bring out their beauty ang recognise the quality and master craftsmanship. This fragrance speaks for itself, by looking at all the comments and love one has for this fragrance I can only add to them. My outlook is on the current formulation one would find at the stores or online right now. It's great. This is a perfect example of why I love this hobby so much, a reminder that there is DIFFERENT and unique scents out there.. This has such a memorable scent trail behind it. The leather and violet are perfect the petroleum note is there but don't let that scare you, it's just a soft artistic touch to let you know that this is a mans fragrance. The longevity and projection is what one would only expect from a high dollar niche fragrance and the bottle is perfect for this conduction.

Sometimes I buy something blindly I think I would love and at first I hate it, then over time grow to appreciate it then wear the heck out of it.
I am so happy I found a 50ml vintage version of this, I hear it a better formulation, I will be the judge of that. I got it for 40$ shipped off an auction site, I don't think they knew what they had bc I see it going for triple digits. I will update shortly and let you know my opinion on the vintage formulation..

9.5/10 overall

2015
spray_and_pray

I am not sure who is the nose/s behind this but they are without a doubt one of the biggest game changers in men's fragrance. Absolute genius. This juice is on another level. One that no other fragrance I've come across has reached. I'm seriously convinced this is the apex of men's fragrance. I'm 25 and like most 20 somethings I enjoy many of the new releases. I'll admit i'm a 1 Million addict. But while fragranes such as 1M may garner more compliments, Fahrenheit is the one I reach for the most when I wear a scent strictly for myself. Infact, I have yet to recieve a compliment on Fahrenheit but I don't care. You know its fragrance love when you wear something bold that isn't popular with your age group just because you love the scent so much. It truly takes someone who understands the art of fragrance to appreciate Fahrenheit's unique and complex composition. If you're in your 20's I wouldn't recommend this as a club scent. That's what the 1 Million's and the Le Male's of the world are for. Fahrenheit is more for those personal and intimate moments. Trust me, don't pass this one up. For some, it takes multiple testings to finally understand Fahrenheit and appreciate it. It took me 6 testings over the span of a year. Give Fahrenheit a chance. When it finally clicks, you'll be hooked.

Fahrenheit is truly a connoisseur's dream.

A++

16
2015
Irisaddict

I fell in love with this fragrance in the 90's when it drifted through the sultry summer air from the tanned clean shaven jawlines of handsome, well dressed continental men. Original, sophisticated yet somehow playful and above all dangerously addictive.

I always remembered it as a unique fragrance but haven't experienced it for a while and had mentally relegated it to the 'classic' shelf; a scent of nostalgia not of now. Then a couple of weeks ago a male friend called round quickly and I found myself paying more attention to the aftershave he was wearing rather than the conversation but not wanting to appear over familiar I didn't ask what he was wearing. The memory of the scent stayed with me and when I next ran into him I was so pleased he was wearing it again and this time didn't hesitate to ask..

'Fahrenheit' he replied, 'I found an old bottle and decided to use it up'! Since that night I have fallen in love with Fahrenheit all over again! :) The fact that after all these years Fahrenheit remains such a unique scent has somehow restored my faith in the perfume world, while so many fragrances these days are lacking in longevity and originality, Fahrenheit still manages to surprise, seduce and quite frankly knock my socks off!

I've also just realised that I haven't even mentioned anything specific about the perfume notes themselves and that's part of the magic. Deconstructing Fahrenheit would be like trying to pin down an ocean breeze; it's the mysterious glint in the eye of a handsome stranger that catches you off guard, a fragrance that awakens your senses and makes your heart flutter, clean yet complex and mischievous, suave yet masculine. A true masterpiece of perfumery.

An epitome of Class and manliness, Undeniably one of the very few best fragrances ever created for Men. A Dashing Fragrance for year round.

07
2015
Rick Bennett

Absolutely bloody marvellous scent.
I tested today comparing a sample of 2010 vintage and a bottle bought last month from Geneva airport duty free. The review is the same for both except that the one marked difference I found was that the 2010 version held on to its "power" phase much longer before it became a skin scent. Otherwise, frankly, I couldn't tell the difference.
It starts off eye-watering petrol, grease, with leather (or sweaty skin?) underneath. A bit later I also get a medicinal (Germoline) thing going on. You have to get your head round all that, but when you do, you'll want to keep going back and spraying it over and over again. Then, strong leather, the most fantastic leather scent ever. And a bit of lavender.
It's pure cave man in its power phase. Like a super macho, cool, handsome car mechanic putting on his leather jacket after his shift. Yet really classy and unique at the same time. It makes me feel like I'm Marlon Brando on a motorbike.
Longevity: long. Silage: for me, moderate (aka BIG)
Love the stuff. The original is still better than all the flankers.
How could any man not want this?
September 2015

kuroicigarette

I love the leather, musk and flower notes.

It's incredibly sexy and I have repurchased, again and again and again, as I have for the past 22 years. There's nothing dated about this scent, it's timeless and a classic.

BigQhatesyou

To me this smells like new leather, freshly ripped leaves and freshly snapped wood. combined these do give off a gasoline-ish vibe, but i wouldnt say it smells like gasoline as others have mentioned.

this was a blind buy for me. when i first sprayed it i was really disappointed and didn't care for it at all. after the 3rd time wearing it i really started liking it.

high quality lasts and projects well with minimum sprays.

Its a little too "out there" for me to wear causally but out of all my fragrances this is the one my girlfriend loves the most.

very masculine

9/10

Aug
12
2015
TheFragranceAmateur

It's going to be hard for me to review this fragrance without sounding like a Fahrenheit fanboy. This is my favorite scent of all time, and is utterly masculine and intoxicating with its petroleum vibe. Completely unique with no challengers, Fahrenheit is a classic and yet smells incredibly modern. It has been reformulated many times throughout its life but retains its beauty and I love the current formulation. With this being available on Amazon in a 200 ml bottle at $75, there is no excuse for any fragrance enthusiast not to own this.

Performance: 7.5 - This has the most varied performance among any of my fragrances, sometimes fading after 6 hours, sometimes lasting and projecting all day.

Overall Scent: 10/10 - This encapsulates everything I love about fragrance. Sexy and addicting, I will always wear this in any season or setting.

michakind

This smells like a guy's been working on cars at the mechanic shop (or a gas station) for the past few hours and just walked out into a lightly sweetly scented breeze. Awesome masculine scent.

The first time I tested this, I had been smelling a number of different fragrances in a shop and I just didn't get it. I think all the other scents had primed my nose so what I smelled didn't make sense to my brain and I moved on. For whatever reason, I gave it a second shot a few days later and immediately fell in love with it. It definitely smells like gasoline mixed with something fresh and sweet in a really good way.

S.Banks

Definitely an OG cologne. But, this juice has stood the test of the fragrance time machine, where others have fallen. For those who have not tried this, it's a powerhouse diesel smelling cologne, but still smooth enough to be seductive due to the leather and lavender and other smells. Not extremely modern compared to recent releases, but some things are best left somewhat retro. It's like an air jordan sneaker. Old, but still stylish. Worth a try, I enjoy it the most in hot summers.

22
2015
brandonrizqi

Dior Fahrenheit Pre-reformulation....
Oh what could I say about this fume... Timeless, bold, intriguing frag... Absolutely classic and timeless... Gasoline everywhere.... Since it was produced in 80's, it never been turned down... Yet the reformulation was one of the best reform ever... I truly cant get enough of this... What a gem!

Scent: Leather is definitely its own main notes... Since it's a classic fragrance, you cannot skip the leather... Based with top gasoline scent... What a pleasure... 9/10

Projectivity : Well-blended with skin and project politely.... 2-3 spray and it would project around 3-5 meter... 9/10

Longevity: Last 6-8 hours in normal 2-3 sprays... 9/10

Overall: 9/10 .... Worth the price for designer's line!! One of the best!!

Jul
21
2015
Vegas Pauli

This was my go-to cologne in college in the early 90's, so I am very familiar with this fragrance. I was reading on here how it's changed over the years. Last night I happened to walk past a Sephoria and decided to douse myself with it for old times sake. Overall it has changed, but the main accords and spirit of the scent are still there. Good news is it's still the Fahrenheit of my college days. The "gasoline" note has been tamed down a bit and the sharpness has softened. I's say its lighter and a little soapier than I remembered. I always was reminded of freshly cut sawdust from the old formula. The new one is def woody, just the entire experience has toned down a bit. It's still a great masculine clean complex scent and I feel the reformulation is successful. I have plenty of cologne in my collection for the time being, but when I'm low, I def grab a bottle of this. Thumps up.

Jul
18
2015
anniebanannie

When I was a younger, I got lost in a newly discovered gold mine in my grandparents' village. Just looking over it, was a river channel that ended in a waterfall that split into a cave system. It wasn't unusual for someone to slip, fall, drown and drop into the mine. Counless numbers of young, sweaty, intelligent men with dreams of striking it rich worked there. I remember two of those boys; the two miners were in the waterfall getting water when they saw me crying. I was afraid they'd hurt me but there was bigger possibility of me finding a cave and dying. Stammering, I asked them for help.

They decided to walk me home. One of them hugged me and tried to calm me down while the other gave me water and held my bookbag. I wrapped my arms around the boy and remember him telling me it's ok. I'll be home soon. True to their word, they went downtown to grandparents house. My uniform was soiled greasy, but it smelled of oil and flowers. Hybiscus, lilacs, violets and honeysuckle are abundant there. When we arrived, Grandpa tried to give them cash but they didn't want any. Grandma came in and gave them food and they melted under her attention. I never forgot those guys.

This fragrance smells just like those boys did. Fresh diesel, sinew, rubber and flowers. I don't care if those aren't the actual notes but to a non expert that is enough. I want to be permanently attached to the man that wears this. I for one love the smell of gasoline. There's something strangely appetizing, comforting and perversely intimate about it. Humphrey Bogart in Sabrina. The original Grease boys. Timothy Dalton's James Bond in the Living Daylights would wear this too (just Timothy, not the others). Heck, the Marlboro Man. They suit this. This mythical, romantic, larger than life man that women at some point in their lives either craved or dreamed of. That man that promised excitement and safety. Who was solid, energetic and hardworking. His strength was hidden underneath his charm but potent still. In reality many of us look for men that pretend to be that, but can't retain the character. It takes some suffering, struggle and gratitude to be like that I feel. With that in mind, not many men wear this anymore.

Jul
17
2015
spray_and_pray

Fahrenheit is either love or hate but for the later, the scent can become enjoyable after some time. I was absolutely repulsed by this at first. I loved the bottle, the name, the classic status this frag has attained, basically the whole idea and image that Fahrenheit represents but I could not appreciate the scent for a long time. I bought Fahrenheit & returned it 3 times before keeping it. I could not understand why anyone would want to smell like gasoline/petro but something kept me coming back though. In time I have come to realize that Fahrenheit is much more than just unique notes...

Fahrenheit represents masculinity and to me, it's specifically represents American masculinity. Leather jackets, muscle cars & nasty speed, rock n' roll, tattoos, 80's excess, and a rebellious nature. To me, there is nothing luxurious about Fahrenheit but that is it's beauty. It's raw and in your face. Fahrenheit isn't for pretty boys. I'm not one that usually says certain people can't wear a particular fragrance for whatever superficial reason but Fahrenheit is for the bad boys.

My advice is, be prepared when you test this one. Fahrenheit is relentless and unadulterated. Even if you don't love it on first spray, you won't soon forget it

2015
Kentington

While I'd love to find an old bottle in the blue "burning planet" box (I used to wear that in High School and I loved it, particularly the weird gasoline quality) it's really easy to forget that this is STILL an incredible scent. We fragheads get caught up in the drama of perfume, the strong, personal response we have to the first few sniffs of top notes...but most people will still identify the heart and dry down as unmistakably Fahrenheit.

May
28
2015
smellavision

I remember trying the original back in the early nineties - a killer bomb of gasoline and petrol in the midst of the soon-to-come unisex as well as fresh & clean male perfume market.

Though not to my liking then, I have always admired Fahrenheit for being the game changer it was. My curiosity got the best of me and now twenty years later I had to try it again.

Not as harsh as I remember it - this could of course be due to my ageing or due to reformulation - but the gasoline opening does not seem to be as vile, yet distinctly the (TM) of Fahrenheit.
The middle part and drydown is actually quite nice, too bad I never got to this part in the early years, as I frantically scrubbed it off. Leather, stunning violet leaves and smoky vetiver, really nice.

I respect it and those who wear it - it's just not for me.

May
25
2015
jose.maximo

I bought a couple of Fahrenheit bottles over the last few years. It wasn't my trademark fragrance, but I really liked it and used when it was safe enough, not for work or a family party, but perfect to go out at night or on a date.
However, I blindly bought a 200 mL EdT bottle last month and couldn't be more disappointed with it. I don't know if they have reformulated it recently (my last bottle might have been from 2011), but it isn't the same perfume. Besides being far weaker, characterless, with none of the long lasting notes that made it the 90s beat (I remember my uncle using it and the stunning smell it had), it doesn't last more than 2-3 hours on my skin, a complete waste of money.
It's a shame a company may completely change a product and maintain its name. The actual version is an insult to the original Fahrenheit.

May
22
2015
Little Prince

One must never forget how good this is. Fahrenheit opens with a strong leafy, cut grass, ozonic accord of violet leaves before getting warmer. There starts the introduction of leather, this leather note feels vintage and imagines like a faded, dusted, brown leather jacket worn out by the passing of time. There are also very prominent wood notes that feel very imposing and persistent making this fragrance stand more in the woods rather than the leather category. Finally the nutmeg and honeysuckle with their sweet spicy floral accents and enveloping aroma put a refined final touch. All these notes and accords feel like being seen (actually smelled) in chiaroscuro sepia colors. Although reformulated, rather heavily, (it used to have more intense violet opening, which persisted more in the composition and the transition to leather was more suspended) it remains one of the most charismatic fragrances ever made with bold character and unmistakable identity. This fragrance always makes me wonder how these past days were, where a new release meant something novel, radical, unique and not a night or sport variation of a used theme. Fahrenheits firepower and smell would only be available in niche today. A miracle of modern perfumery.

May
16
2015
ale chop

When I was a child I took this beautiful bottle from my dad's closet and I sniffed a cap...
Today I have my own bottle and I use this drug with no worries...

It smells different every single time when i wear it.
Expensive woods, gasoline (crazy), wet forest and leather...

Caution: Very addictive!

Both vintage and current are 10/10
Reformulation version is different for sure but it still has this character... It's more modern without lavender note which is very strong in the vintage and a bit outdated... also modern version has less of this intensive flower vibe...

I prefer the reformulation version which is better for daily use IMO.

Longevity and sillage
Vintage: 10/10 (monster)
Current: 6/10 (good longevity and fantastic sillage for few hours)

No more than this one line, and no less.

Mar
18
2015
Piscean-Blue

If you've never been exposed to Fahrenheit, the first thing you need to know is it's not quite like the original. It's been through some reformulations (which were, in my opinion, necessary in this case). But unlike many reformulations this remains close enough to the original (very close). The original spirit is very much intact.

What is that spirit? Well basically Fahrenheit is the odor horny teenage boys secrete when they wanna get laid. Dior captured it perfectly. I think that's why you never see it in bargin bins or on sale. Harvesting that horny glandular juice at just the right season is a costly endeavor. The cost must be passed on to the consumer.

Really, I think of this as an unintentional masterpiece. And make no mistake, this is a masterpiece. This is an envigorating pungent leathery violet-laden candy-ish bottle of joy. But it's a naughty joy. And this is what puts so many people off about this, I think. It's about as subtle as Gabourey Sidibe in a string bikini. Just aggresively sexual (in my opinion). Like a gyrating tongue. Like a group of aroused forteen year olds meeting in the woods on a dewy spring night after their parents are asleep. It's so inappropriate. Yet... a masterpiece. And unique. You can't really compare anything to this.

Gotta grudgingly admit, I love the stuff.

Some thoughts:
-If you've never smelled it, don't blind buy. It's a mainstay at Sephora. Stop by and spray a sample. It's a little polarizing. You might hate it.
-Is this a "panty dropper"? Sure! A classic one. But also a specific one. Picture a very handsome but somewhat tacky dude with a bit too much gold on sliding up next to you on a bar stool. Think hickeys you have to hide from your mom. On another note think pubecent passionate young love.
-If your teenage boy is wearing this, start looking through his stuff when he's out. He's up to no good.
-If your teenage daughter is dating a boy who wears this, start looking for ways to sabotage thier relationship.
-It's pricey (frown)! A true classic that never goes out of style. Makes a fantastic gift!
-Ladies, if you're dating a guy who wears this, he's a player. I'm not saying quit him. I'm saying proceed with caution.
-Sillage and longevity are AMAZING.
-Not for the workplace. Don't do it to your coworkers.
-Shines in the club, but not for those who are looking to be an original (this stuff's been around so long and it's so distinct, it's easily indentifiable).
-You can't layer this with other fragrances. Don't try it.
-Pretty decent for a day of mall shopping.
-Not for the beach. It'll attract sea critters.
-If you see it on sale, snatch it up!

Mar
15
2015
marycon

The best men's fragrance i have ever smelled! Period!

ezequiel91

By the way, for me, this fragrance was so nice and i make me feel confident. Addition it was expensive smelles ever!!

26
2015
sani.axe

This one is really volatile. I was looking for a strong and masculine perfume. I read the reviews to this one and it spoke to me, so I ordered it immediately. I was so anxious the moment I got it I had to put it on. My first time ever smelling it was so far away from my expectations from what I've read. I didn't like it at all. I was mad and started raving how it smells cheap and for old men. But I hadn't given up yet. After a while, the initial scent, which was heavy and nauseating faded off and suddenly I started to like it.

The next day was a Saturday night and I was headed out. By now I had grown fond and was eager to welling the great Fahrenheit scent. I put a couple of sprays on and I loved it. You have to wait 20 minutes or so for the smell to settle then it's absolutely amazing.. I LOVE IT, it's what I wanted!

So yeah at first I was 100% repulsed by it...but you have to learn to love it and give it some time to settle in.

*Best way to describe the scent is as someone mentioned before. Flowers soaked in Petrol. The color of the smell matches the bottle.

I don't know why my sillage wasn't all that great, maybe I should put on more? :D

9/10 Hated it, now I LOVE it

Feb
23
2015
Oudy

I wore this when I was 16 years old...I think it had just come out at the time. It was a brilliant scent that smelled like nothing I had ever come across. And there in lies its appeal IMO. you could smell perfumes from here till eternity and not have anything that smells like this. Rich and bright with lavender, familiar and nostalgic with violet and a bit dirty with patchouli and leather and then there is that unidentifiable petroleum note that every one talks about. I do smell that though it's faint. Like sticking your nose in an old tire that has a small puddle of gas in the bottom, or the smell of wood that's just been soaked with starter fluid. I also remember that I had girls following me around like hungry cats following their food bowl being walked out of the kitchen. I haven't owned this gem since the early 90,s, so i can't comment on re formulation issues...but I have smelled it from time to time over the years and it seems just as potent and original as ever... A new classic!


Scent 8/10
Projection 7/10
Fortitude 7/10


Update Feb 23rd
Just purchased a bottle because...why the hell not! Smells as good as I remember...well, it's not as smooth and smells a bit sharper than I remember but all in all its there

Feb
12
2015
mhaddad88

I hated this fragrance the first time I tried it from a sample vial. I thought it smelled like an ashtray. I did, however, give it some second chances and I actually love this scent now. In my experience, at first I got that sort of motor oil kind of scent, but that went away and a very prominent leather smell comes forward. The kind of leather in a new car. As time continues to pass, I notice the smell getting sweeter, almost fruity which eventually became a very prominent note later on in the scent. I had a look at the notes here and it is probably the mandarin that brought the sweetness. Although it took a few tries, I definitely love this scent. One of my problems with it though is I wouldn't really know what a good scenario to wear it is. Everything in me points to night-time date fragrance as the overwhelming masculinity of it can be alluring if your lady friend is into those types of scents.

10
2015
muzzbait

this perfume may divide people. like or hate. and even the people who REALLY like this scent may hate it on particular days. This is for special occasions and you may not enjoy it entirely...

it's mostly leather and solid green (a mix of the violet leaf and vetiver, i hazard...), and there is a tyre accord struck. you will either love that accord or hate it. today i love it. tomorrow, who knows...for me, that's too unpredictable for me. i'm gonna keep my little atomiser decant for those moments. tread carefully with this one...

Feb
09
2015
daithi

Despite all the reformulations, "Fahrenheit" still smells great. The perfume has been so popular in the early 90s and it has been so copied, that nowadays it smells a bit dated and vulgar.

But there's something incredibly attractive in "Fahrenheit". Maybe because it's still so different of the boring woody-synthetic trend that reigns in the word of men perfumery.

It's a "dandy violet", green and sweet, sorrounded by woods and a surpising touch of petrol. It's a love or hate perfume, but I think that all the perfumistas have to recognize that it's one of the most avantgarde and iconic perfumes of the last 50 years.

Feb
08
2015
tdwctdwc

Timeless scent.

A beautiful celebration of sensational violet leaves that are evoking to the senses, further brightened by a zesty orange accord, stirred with smokey vetiver and polished with leather.

There is no scent in existence that highlights violet leaves the way Fahrenheit does.

Stunning, addictive, unique and mesmerizing.

Jan
26
2015
bgarcia294

This is one of my all-time favorites. In my opinion, the scent is just out of this world. It's got great longevity and projection...

On the top, you get a perfectly balanced citrus-green combo. To me this opening smells heavily like lemon oil (which I totally love) blended with fresh-cut greens and chamomile.

Then it progresses into a hydrocarbon-rich woody vibe with some of the citrus on top, and a nice dose of white florals. And of course some leather.

After that, it dries down into a heavenly gasoline-leather combo that just SLAYS........ and still projects pretty well.

In simple terms, this scent reminds me of an old car's leather seat... but in a really good way. I personally think it is a masterfully blended fragrance.

I would definitely recommend this one to anyone over 20. But I would tell you to TRY IT FIRST as this is one of those love it or hate it fragrances.

My Rating:

Scent: 10/10
Longevity: 8/10
Projection: 8/10
Versatility: 10/10

Jan
23
2015
warrioromar

Dior Fahrenheit. What shall I say, my heart starts pumping when I talk about this beauty. Have no words to describe how good it is. if you want to describe Fahrenheit in word, it would be DARING. In past I used to have signature fragrances for a while and change it, as I grew more into fragrances I tend to wear accordingly. But this one is my signature when it comes to FEEL LIKE MYSELF. This is a smell you would wear when you do not give a fu*k to anyone, without being that arrogant pri*k, This is a smell definitely for a manly man. It starts of quite like How a motorbike would smell(good and sexy way) but then subtle on skin in an hour time or so. from first spray to its drydown its amazing, drydown is more subtle and elegant, and starts of very manly, its give you a vibe that the guy who has this tool kit for everything, and will fix his own stuff without calling technician. Who does not admire a guy who can do his own sh*t RIGHT?? SO Fahrenheit is for that person. What would you attract with Fahrenheit? well Fahrenheit attract ladies that likes a MAN IN CHARGE, not some 'metro' or any questionable character. IT IS FOR A MAN WHO DOES NOT TRY HARD. When you wear Fahrenheit you tell the world you own the place, and you will fix any problem, it shows your stronger personality, that in your company you will handle every situation at your ease. and everything will go right. I personally wear Fahrenheit when I feel careless and daring, oh DO NOT FORGET TO WEAR YOUR BLACK LEATHER JACKET to compliment Fahrenheit. Get your daredevil out of your shell. I could write all day long and still not be enough to praise this amazing piece of work, I thank DIOR for introducing this to planet earth. buy yourself keep this as your weapon, you know how and when to use it ;)

18
2015
TAJ1

When i used it first i was greatly disappointed. I was expecting a lot of heavy gasoline, leather and a lot of heavy notes people mentioned in their comments but it was more fresher and lighter then what i thought it would be . I didn't get that silage and projection either. I usualy like arabic woody and leathery strong type of perfumes and compared to them it wasn't that heavy at all.

But wait, i kept it in my drawer , which i usually do with the perfumes if i don't like them. And after one week i went to a festival with my friend who used Tuscan leather that night and i decided to spray this gem on me. And when i sprayed only 5 sprays on me it was like heaven it smelled so unique to me that i can't compare it to any fragrance i used or tested ever. It projects even more than Tuscan leather and not in a way what people think or talking about it. It is very fresh very ozonic and a bit spicy it has some woody notes, yes it has leather but very refined and different leather copared to other leathry fragrances. It has some very nice slight woody feel to it.and i can still smell the musk from my shirt even after 2 days.

my request is that don't just test this fragrance and leave it give it more than 1 try keep it checking but certainly not a blind buy.



For me it is 10 out of 10 fragrance.
it's totally unique and different from any other fragrance in the world.

so here is my score.

Scent : 10/10 i wish i could give extra points. :)
Silage : 8/10 i have many fragrances which can beat the Fahrenheit easily in silage competition but they smells nothing compared to Fahrenheit.
Longtivety : 9/10.

Note : This is very very addictive scent be cautious .

Jan
17
2015
Lesser

Another superb fragrance from Dior! And a masterpiece too!

This fragrance is one of my old loves. I always thought that smells like an old car dealer or mechanics workshop. It has this lovely kerosene or gasoline note that will either make you fall in love and be disgusted. I wore this to work and some of my co-workers complaint about a wile chemical smell like ethanol or gasoline. For me I love that but to them it was very offputting.

As a person that in my younger years used to repair mopeds and later cars I'm very fond of this perfume because it reminds me of all the good times that I have spend as kind of grease monkey on these vehicles.

I really like this perfume and it always sent me back to the old times with all the great fun in the late work hours.

This is also why I must give an overall rating of:

9/10 indeed a superb fragrance

Jan
13
2015
hemp

I have a slight obsession with Fahrenheit. I first got it as a gift in around 1994 when I was a teenager, it reminds me of my youth so it's kind of sentimental to me. I've worn it on and off ever since and I've accumulated a few bottles from different years, 1988, mid 90's, late 90's, 2000's and I have a 2014 bottle. I've read the Fahrenheit review on raiders of the lost scent and I disagree with a few things they say, especially when they call the 2014 version the "vanilla fahrenheit" which they say is closer to the new eau de parfum version. I think those reviewers might have had some kind of olfactory fatigue. I have compared the 2012 and 2014 versions quite a few times and they smell identical except that the 2014 is not quite as strong but has the same staying power. Anyway, all versions smell like fahrenheit regardless and I'll always have it in my collection

10
2015
khosro.zk

This fragrance born 2 years before me, and I love it

Gasoline? Sorry, your nose is not developed. The sharp gasoline type scent that some people describe is because of mixture of chamomile and violet leaves notes. I found it very interesting and unique. Its freshness and cleanness enhanced by the citruses in the top notes. Warm, better to wear in cold days.
Masculine, interesting, with excellent performance. And it is unique. Its good sell from 1988 to now is not without reason; it is because this fragrance is a masterpiece!

I give is 9/10.
Let me smell my arm one more time ...... 10/10!

Rossyh

I know many people on here consider this a masterpiece so I'm going to apologize in advance as they're not going to like what I'm about to write!

I find this fragrance offensive. Really. I can only think of 1 other perfume I've tried/worn which repulses me. I love the smell of gasoline but I get none of that like people claim they do. Maybe I had a bad batch, maybe the reformulation killed it - either way it's just bad. I would genuinely prefer to smell someone's B.O. instead of this and no, that is not an over exaggeration.

It reminds me of that scene from Anchorman where that guy sprays on Sex Panther - Fahrenheit is my Sex Panther.

My score will seem harsh but for me not to even want to smell a fragrance at any stage let alone consider wearing it, I personally cannot rate it any higher.

1/10

Dec
21
2014
Wolfpocalypse Now

This is my favorite "casual" fragrance for most of the year. When I want to wear something fun but not sweet, Fahrenheit is my go-to. The famed "petrol" note, whatever that may be, is absolutely addictive. I can't wear Fahrenheit everyday, but I really look forward to the next time I get to wear it.

It seems from the Fragrantica stats on this fragrance, more people prefer it in fall and winter rather than spring and summer. I personally love it in the spring and summer, even though it does do exceptionally well in the cooler weather. I tend to enjoy sweet and spicy scents in the fall and winter, and Fahrenheit is a nice break from the usual rotation of citrus-focused fragrances that I wear a lot in the warmer seasons.

Anyway, it's a solid 9/10 in my book, and I can't imagine not having it.

Dec
16
2014
fahadharoon

@dianacreole

you are welcome. : )

I have been wearing Fahrenheit for over 10 years now. I still think this is THE best fragrance that i have ever smelled. It is very masculine, gets a load of compliments, has an absolute monster performance in all departments and it is unique (nevertheless very recognizable). It requires a degree of confidence to wear Fahrenheit. Not everyone will like it, as is obvious with the spectrum of appreciation (or otherwise) in the trailing reviews. But those who do like it, adore it. And they will only say that this is nothing less than a masterpiece. I do think that the current formulation is not as strong or lasting as it used to be 10-8 years ago. But it is still solid.

I have garnered only good compliments from this, except one time that i had over-applied it in the beginning. My sister-in-law thought it was extremely strong and offensive. I learned a valuable lesson that day!

I still use it in autumn/winter regularly. And i still love it as much as i used to. Best part is, so does my wife.

Dec
07
2014
Le_Coeur_Gothique

Back in 1988 I was a poor student, and for your information, while the noun is long gone, the adjective still remains. So when I managed to save enough money and buy a gorgeous heavy woolen jacket, I was more than happy to take a long walk downtown and enjoy its comfort, warmth and quality. It was a couple of days before Christmas, and along with a blissful pixie who pretended to be my human girlfriend, we thought it would be a good idea to test some fragrances, and perhaps get a couple of free miniatures. I have to clarify to younger readers that back then most perfume samples were miniature bottles, and not the bland plain vials that they are nowadays. Truth be told, I was looking forward to return home and spray my new jacket with a generous dose of Davidoff by Davidoff, and turn it into my signature jacket soused in my then signature perfume. But what harm could a little window shopping do? So, I, armed with a brand new '80s jacket (which would be thought a curio today) and she, armed with the obligatory '80s perm, headed for the cosmetics stores.
Grave mistake...
A sales assistant who was lurking by the door and surely was a faster shooter than Billy the Kid, managed to shoot three huge sprays of something that nearly knocked me off my feet on my jacket, in less than a second. If she was holding a gun instead of a huge bottle of the most potent and fresh Fahrenheit ever imagined in her hands, I'd be dead before hitting the ground. And I have no doubts that had I tried to duck her attack, she wouldn't hesitate to spray me square in the face, if it had come her way.
I shook the impulse to strangle the harpy on the spot and search for a dry cleaner in the next 20 seconds, and proceeded with our perfume testing.
And then the horror begun...
For the next four months or so, every time I'd put my jacket on, I smelled like someone who was working in a car repair shop or a gas station, although if this was the case, I would be the swankest car repair shop or gas station employee ever.
And to add insult to injury, can you imagine what were the only miniatures that we were given in the end? Yeah, you got it right...
...
Fahrenheit is a heavy scent. A very heavy scent. And of course I'm not talking about its potence in aromatic terms only. Even though it's a prolific scorer in the fields of sillage and longevity (the vintage one at least), it's mainly a very serious player in the field that produces legend material.
I have to admit that Fahrenheit is an incomprehensible scent to me.
Peppery notes, but no pepper! Perhaps it's a dirty trick played by some strange reaction between leather and nutmeg. Since I can't point at any other notes and consider them the culprits for this elusive accord, these two have to be the ones responsible.
And then there's this strange, unique and unequalled (but not necessarily nice) accord, which I'm completely incompetent to decipher and therefore to describe it. Not in an satisfying degree at least.
But perhaps it's worth giving it a try.
Since my nose is no big deal, I rarely talk about notes in my reviews. However, Fahrenheit has kept me wondering since 1988 about this "What the hell am I smelling here Christian?" stuff.
The fragrance has three hesperidic notes (Is "hesperidic" a valid word? Internet has not decided yet, so I apologise in advance for the possible barbarism.)
Well, I don't smell them.
It also has five sweet flowery notes.
I don't smell them either.
So, according to their absence of prominence, none of this eight notes is directly responsible for Fahrenheit's distinctive and unforgettable drydown.
So what is it?
I say that it smells like gasoline soaked sandalwood, that someone was crazy enough to set it on fire, and then put the cinders in the inside pocket of an old leather jacket, which he then wears after the gym and without showering first.
And before extolling my imagination... I've done it...
But it just made the whole thing even trickier, because it added a slight cummin note, and cummin is not included in the scent's pyramid. So, what I finally got with my "analysis" was a hint of something that shouldn't be there at all. Very helping...
I could also say that it smells the way some old taxis used to smell back in the '70s, but maybe my mind is playing tricks, trying to place the leather and diesel/gasoline/kerosene/motor oil notes to a matching vessel. However, I can see some connection here, since I believe that if we ask ten people how the inside of a brand new or a very old car smells like, five of them will say that they smell of leather, the other five that they smell of fuel, and all ten of them that they smell of Fahrenheit.
But maybe it's these very same oddities about it, which render Fahrenheit one of the few instantly recognizable fragrances in my book.
I have no idea how the current formulation smells like, and to be honest I don't care. I don't love and I don't hate Fahrenheit. For me it's a perfect example of uniqueness and an unparalleled specimen of aweless perfumery, but I'm still unable to decide whether this example is a paragon or a byword, and whether Fahrenheit's universe and mine are any parallel at all. But my personal likings have nothing to do with the objective stature of the fragrance. Fahrenheit has become a cornerstone and a legend over the years, and it doesn't give a damn if I like it or not. It's just there, too busy being itself.

Dec
06
2014
Gator83

I don't care what anyone says. If you want to smell like a gas pump or mechanic, knock your self out because that's what I smell. It's dated, old and out of touch (not that it ever was in touch). If you can smell something and it reminds you of gas, that's saying a lot by itself. I worked in fragrance and not one women ever said they liked this, it was more like OMG is that gas in a disgusted face.

04
2014
dianacreole

This is my all time fav cologne on a man. I like it so much that I have owned bottles in the past just so I could inhale it from time to time or to push it on men that I had dated in my single years! To me, it's THAT good. I close my eyes and inhale every time I'm at a boutique just to get that nice dose of gasoline, leather and cucumbers. I've never been successful in converting a man to wear this one -- either you love it or hate it I guess. But make no mistake, I swoon over this one.

Thank you to all the men that wear it!

Dec
04
2014
silentman26

One of a kind, bold, mysterious. Opens with a strong petroleum vibe and grass ... with citrus, warm spices and a pleasant mix of violet and nutmeg ... and then blends with leather/musk and a deep smell of sandalwood, cedar and a hint of dry patchouli in the background. Brings back many memories and it's my signature scent for many years now. Fahrenheit is one of the best and most successful perfumes... and even though it's in the market for more than 25 years... remains modern and better than most of the new fragrances. The best green fragrance by far. With projection and longevity to the maximum... and enormous sillage... A ground breaking masterpiece!

Dec
04
2014
guerlainfreak

An excellent example that quality transcends time. I have always been a fan of Dior's output, with minor exceptions, and Fahrenheit was one I did not care for when it first came out. I have been going through a journey of all the classics from the 80's and I must say... this is a marvelous composition. What I found interesting is that Fahrenheit is like a farewell to the 80's... you get the macho, overpowering presence of the decade combined with the toned-down, unisex sensibilities of the 90's... Anyhow, forget about the nonsense, labeling, categories... this is a wonderful scent. Like a worn out leather jacket that reeks of violet leaves. It is as close as a comfort scent as you will ever get close to. If you love it in yourself, great. If you love it on your lover, power to you. If you just appreciate what great perfume craftsmanship is all about, terrific. Again, fragrances are about the experience, the deep-based and fleeting memories it evokes. Art that vanishes, but leaves its beauty's footprint. Don't let nametags hold you back. Enjoy the ride, for better or for worse.

2014
Brian's Wee Sister

Some fragrances should be sprayed in the air, allowing one time to take fifteen steps back before walking slowly forward into any minuscule droplets which may remain in the air. This, my friends, is one of those fragrances. I read once that Fahrenheit was the scent of choice for most gay men. I don't know how such a poll could be conducted, but there you go. What's interesting is that every gay friend I've ever had has loved wearing Fahrenheit!

Fleurissima

Apologies to all the gents out there if you do love this one, but as a female and a huge lover of many men's fragrances and Dior, I am not fond of this scent at all; in fact I cannot stand it.

The scent to me is of very potent, woody, peppery notes (nice) coated in kerosene and... glue (not as nice).

Maybe it's the masculine nose that is attracted to the strength of Fahrenheit, but this scent is too overpowering to capture any femme interest and intrigue.

Nov
17
2014
John Mason

A very dear friend of mine wears this.
You can smell the perfume first, and then the person comes in. Not the other way around as we are used to. The sillage is enormous and I think it should be. It has to evoke a strong, powerful presence. Presence you have to feel before you actually know or see who it is.
It overwhelms you and subdues you completely, you are a slave to it.
Please, watch the video advertisement. Can you feel it? The presence. I don't know what it is, but it's there. You are following it with your eyes and you don't even know what it is, or why are you following it. The man gets out of the elevator and keeps walking - where is he? What is THAT? This is the feeling this fragrance evokes in me.
It's a heavy leather explosion carried by earthy notes of patchouli and vetiver. Yet, there is this easiness to it, orange lemony tones and freshness of herbal lavender. But it's very subtle, still present. The combination stings your eyes, but you keep them open, to see the thing, that is felt, but never seen.
The presence.
And this fragrance is all about that.

Nov
17

The two together made me recoil without scrunching my face so as not to offend the SA who suggested it to me. I will try again and see if the air had something there to distort Fahrenheit's beauty.

One spray on me:
Sillage: a foot
Longevity: 3-4 hours
Rating: 1/5 for now but may review in future

2014
80sfiend

Oh Fahrenheit! One word - delicious. Back in the early 90s I had a crush on a guy who wore this. Maybe that's why I like it so. It's probably not a fragrance for everyone, especially if you like to be heavy handed. It can be overpowering. But it is quite unique, masculine, warm and smooth. From a distance it's still great, but to really appreciate it, you have to get up close to the skin, and I guess that is the intention of wearing something leathery and musky like this. It probably suits more the charismatic type who might like the attention - but just don't put on too much. These days when that same guy wears it out on the town, no joke, the ladies come flocking and compliment him. How do I know? Well I just had to marry that man, didn't I... ;)

Nov
08
2014
browne54

My signiture fragrance and so dear to my heart. Also the best compliment I have ever received "your cologne is causing me to ovulate".

Nov
07
2014
Buysblind

I used to mow the lawn in my backyard and along one swath of grass there was a large honey-suckle bush. The sweet, floral aroma of the honey-suckle would mix with the gasoline from the mower and the smell of leather on my hands from my work gloves. That's the closest I can get to describing what Fahrenheit smells like. Sweet, fresh specific floral notes of honey-suckle over petrol and the worn, rugged smell of leather. But my description really doesn't do it justice. Fahrenheit is like its own planet in the fragrance universe, and it's one of a strange, swirling atmosphere, equal parts enchanting and toxic. Fahrenheit's bottle represents its contents precisely, from dark shades of red and black to higher hues of orange and pale yellow. All in all, this is one hell of a fragrance that must be sniffed to be even remotely understood. A timeless classic, that feels modern and cutting edge almost 30 years after its release date. If you have never smelled this before, go out and get your nose on it! Projection and longevity are superb.

Nov
07
2014
CUMTHRU$T0MPN!

Ok im goin to start off by saying i do love this fragrance but im going to be critical of it in my review for those who have never smelled Fahrenheit benefit. The leather is very strong but the scent I take away most from CDF is the violet. When i was a kid we had these flowers that grew in our front yard and I was told they were honeysuckles even tho I dont believe that they were, but thats the scent I pick up most then tne leather hits you like a hurricane. I have to agree with most reviews, versatility is lacking :( but that doesnt make this a bad scent. Its just difficult to find a perfect occasion to wear this Beautiful scent. So test before you buy because I know most guys want that everyday scent for home,work & date. This is not it. But for the collector this is a must have.

9/10

Oct
21
2014
Santiago

Fahrenheit: leather jackets and motorcycles.

where i live, some years ago (80s and half 90s) it was considered the perfume of playboys (and wannabes) so it was pretty popular. still today i can notice it also on young people (20+). i'd say, maybe too common: you can't be unique with this perfume.

i love this perfume, it was my signature scent, sometimes i even sprayed it over my leather jackets and it still smelled nice. it evokes faraway, exotic lands, hot nights from the east and warm sunsets.

someone says it has notes of gasoline or motor oil, i don't know, but it suits also that kind of style. i think there's something "macho" in this scent.

projection medium/high, longevity is huge on me, i can smell it even the day after.

Oct

2014
Ivano

I bought it yesterday at a store and man, I feel so ripped off. This is the second Dior product that I buy this year (I bought my girlfriend Blooming Bouquet) with the same feeling. Both smell incredible, specially Fahrenheit, but they don't last on skin at all. They become skin scents in less than an hour and longevity is 3 hours maximum. I don't recommend buying this only because of that. It is a pity that we lost this masterpiece along the way with the current formulation. I hope they do something about it because I don't like the Parfum version.

Hedphuq

It's so oily, probably due to the violet. It does smell like petrol, you can tell instantly. But don't underestimate it. It's a very rich smell, well blended, warm and masculine. Smells like an old rusty mustang, in a garage with gasoline soaked floor. Do not trust anyone who tells you you could only wear this suited up. It fits perfectly to a leather jacket and blue jeans. It can be a bit harsh in the opening, and you should be careful on a trigger, no wonder, it's an eighties fragrance, even though it was reformulated couple of times. Although I don't think it's dated, just not for everyone. I'm barely 20 and I wear this. I love it, I don't care.

2014
syedammar

This is my first review on fragrantica, I am from germany so please excuse my english. I got a 5 ml sample of it because of it being praised as one of the best fragrance for men. After using up all of it in 2 weeks, I still dont have words how to describe it. I'm 23 and I think I can pull it off pretty well according to me :P but I dont know whats wrong with general public choice in colognes nowadays. Its like I didnt get a single compliment rather people were kind of intimidated by me. Maybe this is because of the heavy nature of this cologne, yes its heavy but not loud actually i dont have exact words to describe the smell so best way to put it is like bass(low frequency) in music. I love it on myself and cant stop myself from sniffing wrist, projection is good but longevity is an issue (1-2 hrs) then it becomes skin scent or maybe im too harsh on it because I havent been complimented on it :D. Coming to smell, it smells to me exactly like freshly cut grass. People saying it has gasoline, leather, ozonic notes have no idea what they are talking about. You can yourself go and smell from any shop (do smell on wrist not on strip). Its a really unique scent, I cant get how the creator thought of such a scent while making it.
So my rating would be
Scent = 10/10 for me, 8.5/10 for other men, 3/10 for women
Longevity = 6.5/10
Projection = 8.5/10

2014
Phoenix1

Mature? My right eye...I spent quite a few hours reading all of the reviews on here about this gem and words like "Too mature", "dated" or "Gasoline" or "Dirty Mechanic" kept cropping up...WTF are you guys talking about? I understand these are personal opinions but in my book WRONG personal opinions....You may not like the fragrance. I get that too..."not my cup of tea"...Really? What is your cup of tea? AdG? The most boring fragrance ever created? Give me a break peeps. This stuff to me is like a breath of fresh air from the Designer market. A fragrance with all intents and purposes could EASILY be classified as niche. One of my new faves. I, like many, wore this as a teen and now I'm in my mid 40's and this stuff simply rocks. I think with the reformulation, they made it dated. you CAN actually wear this as a daily scent (which I do) and I don't believe any of that bullshit saying you cannot wear this stuff in the heat. I live in Florida and as long as you back off the sprays, it's even BETTER with some heat, IMO...The scent trail is longer and more robust with this one...two sprays in the hot summer is all you need. I get more compliments with this one, than most of my other fragrances which are WAY over 100 bucks...Declaration Essence is the other and MFK Pluriel are the other two that women tend to enjoy on me. Oh, and of course, Aventus...I'm not going to bore you with how I think it smells since many have described it on here VERY well...but its simply one of the best fougre's out there....Hands down and EVERYONE should have this in their collection. It's unique, modern and ohhhhh so good....

25
2014
magimagi999

It's so sad that I don't know how the original thing smelled like, and the first reformulation is only a vague memory. The first time I smelled it - it was a total NO. I thought to myself "there's so much gasoline you can't seriously wear that", so I made the mistake of not having it (though changed apparently).

But 4-5 years ago I decided to give it a second chance - still too harsh for me (didn't even wait for it to dry, I just said 'no', to prove my younger self right) - yet another mistake as it was apparently the 3rd incarnation of it and today we are having the 4th if I'm not mistaken.

Well 2 days ago - third chance, why not - I was completely BOUGHT by the fragrance, waited for at least a good 30 minutes or so for it to settle down and see its true colours. A rewarding, strong, masculine smell, just like described it's ozonic, really fresh at first, almost like cutting through a fresh cucumber, but it was the floral scents that were the real kicker for me. I was able to still smell it at the end of the day which was terrific, but I bought a little sample first, as I didn't believe my luck with good ole Fahrenheit.

Well apparently I'm not the only one who thinks that the good stuff you try on and the stuff you're buying differ. I got the 2nd or 3rd formula at best to try, but my sample must be the 4th I guess, because still ozonic it loses that feel quickly on my skin and dries down so quick, that although the smell stays with you for at least 6h it's getting really weak in the first 30-60 minutes and stays more closely to the skin.

I am dissapointed! Finally, when I got to appreciate this great scent it is a mere shadow of itself.

Sep
24
2014
Pete89

This is definitely a classic among fragrances, nobody can argue that. Most fragrance collectors have this in their collection, or have had it in the past. It has earned its tracks. I decided to try Fahrenheit too recently, but I didn't quite like it. I'm not saying it's bad - it's definitely a unique smell - but I feel like there are better fall/winter/night colognes out there, like Burberry London, La Nuit De L'Homme or Dior Homme Intense.

Another problem I have with Fahrenheit is that it's not a very subtle or classy scent; more rough and 'in-your-face' (hence the 'gasoline' smell and reviews from others stating the possible headaches). The fact that it's so heavy limits the use of Fahrenheit to colder months and nights; it will be too cloying in the spring and summer, and too offensive to use for casual/office/work purposes.

If you're looking for a classic night-out scent for men, by all means try this out (sample first though)! If you're looking for a subtle and classy date fragrance, skip this one.
