I'm getting faint violets and a hint of leather that fades rapidly down to a trace of spicy forest. The oily leather note that was so gorgeous is simply gone. The violets that set the leather off are barely perceptible.

The overwhelming note I get from this new bottle is that atrocious aromachemical that smells like watery wet cardboard.

Dior really screwed me this time, I would return it but I stupidly threw the box away before I cracked into the bottle.

I would caution anybody out there buying ANYTHING from Dior to open the package in the store in front of the SA and make sure you're getting what you paid for before walking out. Horrible.

Absolutely amazing. The scent that got me into perfumery. To me, the "petrol" note is not nearly as strong as some people seem to think, and, throughout the fragrance's evolution, it begins to soften and gives way to a seamless combination of leather and lavender, with other notes in the background affirming its mysterious nature. In my opinion, one of the only scents that truly manage to be fresh and warm at once. 10/10

2014
hedward

I own a vintage bottle with the gold, blue and red packaging. Now.. firstly the current formulation isn't (obviously) as long lasting as the vintage but the smell is still very similar. The vintage has noticeably more chamomille and honeysuckle which give it a smell that I can only descirbe as honey on freshly cut grass. The current formula has that very same effect but it's overshadowed by the leather which is far stronger and harshes than in the older ones. Vintage also is overall much softer and more "complete smelling" while the reformulations still smells of Fahrenheit it lacks that special something and leaves you craving for more.

Now the current formula is not bad at all, but it didn't have enough detail to make me fall in love with this masterpiece - which later on happened during my first spray of the vintage.

Paulo Rocha

I bought the first bottle in the 90's. Gorgeous, strong, masculine, different. After it was gone I spent some years navigating through different waters, but as lately I've decided to revisit some of my favourites of my 30's (Ralph Lauren Safari, Kenzo Pour Homme)... what a disappointment! These ones haven't changed much, but Dior's is quite another thing! I can't even say that "maybe my memory has betrayed me" because I finished the old bottle just a couple of years ago. The old one was fabulous; the modern...let's just say that I will use it one time or another, "just for the old times".

Mrbigbigtoe

I bought a 1.7oz bottle from walmart for $50 about a year ago. So I really don't know which formulation I have, but it smells so good. Honestly this is by far the strongest EDT I have as far as projection goes.
Longvity is also really well, but could be a little better. It typlically lasts on a hot day for 10 hours.
On cold days it will last normally about 8-9 hours.

Then again that is really good lasting power for ANY EDT.

Scent 10/10
For young or old? Well really there is a lot of mixed reactions. Many say only the bold wear Fahreheit. So to be honest (TBH) I think of myself as a bold individual. So of course I wear it:) BTW I'm 18

Really the scent isn't truly old OR young. It's just straight up sexy:)

Lasting power 7/10
Projection power 6/10
(with 3 sprays, because anymore will be overpowering/cloying)

So really, this fragrance is absolutely what I would call a masterpiece. BUT, I wish that the projection was better. Then again, this is NOT a fragrance that someone would want to have too much of it on. So 1 spray on your neck the first time you wear it and go from there. If for everyday in the office (as older men with jobs would say) I would say 2 sprays max. If you're feeling frisky/bold/sexy go for 3:) NO MORE THOUGH.

AMAZING fragrance.

Jul
24
2014
Sailinder

Name: Fahrenheit.
Perfume company: Christian Dior.
Perfumers: Maurice Roger, Jean Louis Sieuzac.
Launched in: 1988.
Concentration: Eau de toilette.
Gender: Male.
Professional fragrance classification:
The Technical Commission of the French Society of Perfumers;
B7 - Fleuri bois / Floral woody.
Michael Edwards; Woods fresh / Bois frais.
My rating (on paper and on my skin): 10/10, 1988-2001 edition.
Date of review: July 22nd, 2014.

The original version of Fahrenheit was a stunning masterpiece, consisting of various magnificently crafted contrasts, which maintained tensions throughout the perfume. It was an elusive, intriguing and intoxicating fragrance. On the skin it transformed from a slightly cool and sweet opening, to a literally breathtaking blend of spices and flowers during the heart, accompanied by a long-lasting impression of glowing woods from the base.
To me, Fahrenheit, has always been the ultimate autumn scent, combining the lustre, tranquillity and melancholy of the season; the last show of summer splendour with everywhere the brilliant fall of colourful leafs... rainy days with an earthy smell... a world preparing for the coming winter

The first reformulation* was released in early 2002 and contained significantly less violet leaf oil, less honeysuckle, less methyl heptine carbonate, less methyl octine carbonate etc. It was the first time the gasoline scent - largely deriving from the camomile note - became noticeable, but it wasnt that distinct yet. It was still reasonably blended with all the other notes. The first reformulation was weaker overall and emanated fewer contrasts in comparison to the vintage, but was still a potent fragrance. While the vintage was 10/10, the first reformulation was 9.0/10 in my opinion.

An interesting subject is why Christian Dior reformulated Fahrenheit for the first time. Fahrenheit had proven to be a tremendous commercial success since its release. Perhaps sales figures had dropped by 2002? Well, not according to the Dior company itself; they claimed that it still was one of their major bestsellers along with Poison, Dune etc. Furthermore, Dior was a manufacturer of other luxury goods, like clothing and jewellery, all very desired and profitable. So they werent exactly losing money and therefore decided to save on perfume ingredients. Nevertheless, companies are always afraid to lose money (in the long run). So, perhaps modernization was the cause. Perfume history shows us that aquatics became the dominating perfume trend during the nineties, from Davidoffs Cool Water, also launched in 1988, to the magnificent Leau Dissey pour Homme in 1994 and so on. Was the need perhaps felt at Dior to lighten Fahrenheit for the changed market? I doubt this, because in the nineties there was also another new development which proved very successful; the gourmand perfume. The first very successful gourmand perfumes were Thierry Muglers Angel from 1992 and A*Men from 1996, which opened the road towards ever sweeter, but also heavier perfumes again! - Givenchys Pi -1998, Rochas Man -1999, Lotita Lempicka au Masculin -2000, Yves Saint Laurents M7 -2002, Gucci pour Homme -2003 etc. The nineties were also the era that gave birth to unisex perfumes - CKOne -1994, Salvador Dalis Dalimix -1996 etc., and the eau de parfum concentration within male perfumes - Guerlains Hritage -1992, Yves Saint Laurents Opium pour Homme -1995 etc. All these very different developments and perfumes, all being successful in the nineties and early two-thousands, show us that diversity and creativity were highly appreciated by people who in return increasingly spend money on haute parfumerie.
Neither did the 2002 reformulation happen because of the first severe IFRA amendments. The IFRA issued restrictions on bitter orange oil, oakmoss, treemoss, cinnamyl nitrile etc. during the early two-thousands. Animal-derived notes like deer musk or civet didnt even need banishment or restrictions by the IFRA since these were already banned or legislated. Pressure from societies and animal protection organisations had made an end at much animal cruelty - a truly positive transformation in the fragrance world! My point is, there had never been bitter orange oil, oakmoss or animalic notes in Fahrenheit. No, as far as I can see, Dior/LVMH had Fahrenheit only reformulated in an attempt to maximize their profit. For this they diluted the original formula. If this is indeed the case, I find this nothing less than despicable. The human mind connects strong emotional and vivid memories with scents. By continuously and drastically changing a perfume, we are somehow deprived of our memories.

Fahrenheit was reformulated for the second time around 2006. In this version the 'gasoline scent' emerged clearer at the surface, and it also became the leading note during the middle phase caused by the fact that several other ingredients were toned down further. In this regard its also worth mentioning that when a bottle of Fahrenheit of the vintage, second and third version isnt preserved perfectly and kept from warmth and light, in time, the gasoline scent will become noticeable, stronger, or will turn into a dominating smell in the entire fragrance!

The current Fahrenheit was launched end of 2009/ early 2010; the gasoline scent is absent, but overall the perfume has been diluted and weakened even further. Due to several IFRA restrictions on aroma chemicals like linalool and lyral has it become a soapy fragrance, almost without contrasts or transitions. The smell is still unique and recognizable to me, but only on a paper strip I can detect some contrasts and transitions, on my skin it has become flat and one-dimensional.
I can imagine that someone who never knew the vintage version could like it, but my memory would always keep comparing. The unique smell that made Fahrenheit the outstanding floral woody perfume it once was, has disappeared with the third reformulation for about 95%.

Much to my regret, I have just one bottle of the classic 1988 version; a 50 ml./1.7 oz. silver limited edition bottle produced in 1993 (batch code 3646P), which I use quite sparingly - mostly just once or twice a year. It took me many years and a lot of failed purchases, but in the end I was delighted to find this one in a great condition! From experience I can say that it has become extremely difficult to still find a genuine bottle from the first version, kept in perfect condition.

To finish my review, hereby descriptions of the appearances:
Vintage version, 1988-2001; the box is deep dark blue at the top - in which Fahrenheit has been written in white letters -, followed by deep red in the middle and finally creamy yellow at the bottom.
First reformulation, 2002 - 2006; the box is medium blue at the top, this merges into a dark brownish red section - in which in white letters Fahrenheit has been written -, and this finally merges into a deep red colour. Three quarters of this box is in that deep red colour.
Second reformulation, 2006 - 2010; the box is dark brownish red at the top and this merges into a deep red colour for the rest of the box. Above the middle of the box, still in the red area Fahrenheit and Eau de Toilette have been written in silver letters.
Third reformulation, 2010 to date; the box looks almost identical as the box from the second reformulation. The colour is again dark brownish red at the top which merges into a deep red colour for the rest of the box. However, above the middle of the box, still in the red area, now only Fahrenheit can be found in silver letters. Eau de Toilette isnt written anymore in silver, but in smaller letters at the middle of the box in a light red colour. This is also the version in which the cap of the bottle has been altered to a straightforward looking vertical cap.

S. Singh

_____________________________________________________

* In 2002 Fahrenheit was released for the first time in a different coloured box. This indicates to most perfume lovers the first reformulation. However, there are some older Basenoters who insist that Fahrenheit was first reformulated much earlier than 2002, that is in 1994 or 1998. Now, could it be that Christian Dior had the large amount of chemical notes decreased in 1994 and/or in 1998 to make the perfume smell a bit less toxic/more consumer friendly? Could it be that the first reformulation was in production from 1998 to 2006, and that the box wasnt changed at exactly the start of the new perfume formula but a few years later? Unfortunately, I just cant tell! When the first reformulation exactly happened will probably remain a recurring issue in perfume discussions. And it can be persistent to me as well, especially since I have a distant recollection from a bottle that I bought at the end of the nineties that didn't smell as powerful as Fahrenheit from the early nineties. Well, reality is that in the nineties most perfume lovers, including me, had never heard of perfumes being reformulated, so there was no cause at all to pay attention. Nevertheless did I try many times in the last few years to verify a pre-2002 reformulation, but mostly due to a few quite instable chemical compounds in the vintage Fahrenheit that have disintegrated over time, has it become virtually impossible to find unscathed bottles to perform reliable tests.

Jul
22
2014
Liamsardea

We all know this fragrance- I'm only going to translate (our) mental processes to the best of my ability.

Masculinity bottled.

Ultimately, Diors Fahrenheit is a very distinctive fragrance. It is described as something: Truly embodying the pioneering spirit of Dior, Fahrenheit entered a territory thus far unexplored by a fragrance: the land of dreams, of fancy, of the quest for meaning and the infinite. A legendary bold, powerful and magnetic signature that plays on hot and cold, masculinity and sensuality.

The beauty of this fragrance lies in its ballsy, animal-like character. It is unlike any other fragrances because it utilizes a very unique series of notes to create magic in a bottle. It isnt moreish in a gourmand sense; it is the anti-gourmand, but rather a warming hot, red and masculine scent thats protective and intoxicating.

I think of dry earth touched by petroleum rain from a gasoline cloud, hot oozing magma from dark igneous rock only fueled more and made destructive from a dousing of unleaded. Unlike many other fragrances that I smell, this doesnt evoke calm or serenity, but rather a sense of self-pride and immense hedonism.

Its undeniably a fragrance you need to dedicate yourself too; that is, considering the infinitely masculine nature of the fragrance, you need to be in the right headspace to wear it.

The gasoline note is best described as ozonic and almost processed. It is combined with the dryness of tobacco leaf, tonka bean, sumptuous leather, chamomile, cedar, sandalwood, amber, nutmeg and pepper to create the earthy, dustiness I prior described. These notes are the ones that require some dedication to wear. You cannot, nor should not wear this when you have a headache, because the dryness can be too much. The heaviness and the pleasant deepness of these notes make the fragrance red and almost aphrodisiac like.

However, the gasoline is purely mind-blowing and is like an artful rust on the composition of this fragrance. It gives it the three dimensional quality and also serves to create something attractive, surprising and unexpected. The standout note in the mix.

Whilst the top note contains the ozonic gasoline scent, through rather masterful blending, the perfect fougere and citrus blend of lavender, bergamot, vetiver and lemon come through with a hint of chamomile bud. Fresh violet leaf amongst linalool come out amazingly also.

All these notes give it a sexy character. Someone below said that this fragrance is perfect for communicating sexuality. I think this notion is perfect- as in fragrances you get the polarity of femininity, ie. a profusion of florals, but sometimes the male pole is ambiguous. Fahrenheit by Dior is frankly, testosterone bottled, it is what males have been missing.

"A fragrance shared unintentionally by the perfect event and encounteror so to speak." @lassmichdich PERFECTION

The dry-down shifts from the boozy and ozonic character to a harmonious blend. The pepperiness stays; barely tame, where now the citrus and flower is elevated a little more behind the faade of gasoline. Lavender and violet leaf are now but a stern whisper, and the chamomile is, in my opinion, very important in this mix. It is the glue holding citrus and gasoline together and without it, the headiness of gasoline would figuratively be too corrosive and kill the delicates. Chamomile and its herbal, sun-dried character is the aperitif for the gasoline- or the base in fragrance talk.

Citrus in the mix keeps the juice oily, combating the dry character of some of the woody/fougere notes to keep everything whet/wet, both you and your palette plus the fragrance.

All in all, Fahrenheit is a seasonless fragrance. Many would argue its strictly for winter, however some of the more floral notes are perfect for spring and summer. I must say the gasoline is a bit heavy the first 10 minutes and a bit dizzying (like literal gasoline) but I swear its addictive- the thematics similarities are quite humorous!

Fahrenheit screams manliness. To wear this you cannot be unconfident. Stand tall and be proud of all that you do. An individual with doubt and dubiousness cannot wear this fragrance to full effect.

Rawr. 4/5.

Jul
14
2014
[email protected]@r

I had the same experience with Fahrenheit as almost everyone else. I tried it and didn't like it. Then tried again...still didn't like it. Finally I just sprayed it on my arm and let it do its thing. I got the strong opening. It does smell like oil, gas, or petroleum something along those lines. However, I get the musk, violet, and leather all working together as the cologne starts to develop. After about an hour I was left with a scent that was reminiscent of cutting the grass on a warm but damp humid afternoon. After you cut the grass you fill up your lawn mower with gas/oil in your garage. After you are done you put on your favorite worn leather jacket and kick back in the lawn full of cut grass and flowers. The dry down is full bodied, complex, mysterious, woody, and leathery all at the same time.

I need more testing but I am seriously considering buying myself a small bottle because a little goes a long way!! This scent is definitely uber-masculine and will draw attention and most likely compliments.

2014
stinkypnutz

Dior Fahrenheit is a "smooth violet bomb." Violet persists throughout the whole fragrance and it is not extremely sharp. The violet note is very well complimented by the leather and mandarin and is pure harmony on my skin. I love this stuff. This fragrance may be playing tricks on my nose because I can barely smell it projecting, but I know it is. Very interesting and unique fragrance by Dior. I do not have time to go through all the notes or this fragrance's versatility, so maybe another time.

Versatility
7/10 - I will explain this at a later date.

Longevity
8/10 - Still smell this on me the next day.

Projection
8/10 - I know this is projecting, it is consistently hitting me in the face. It just seem soft.

Scent
8/10 - What a Gem by Dior

27
2014
zkxnyi278

I really love this stuff. The image it smells like to me is if you hopped in a car with new leather seats on a hot muggy day that's been sitting for half of it, after peeling a nearly over ripe orange by hand, go to pick up a mechanic friend who just got off work and still smells like it and then go for a drive in the country while everything's still wet from a recent rain. At first Really strong leather and intense orange, gasoline , oil, metal, softer smelling nutmeg, and some really nice very musty and wet grass + fallen tree & wet dirt smell hanging out in the back at first but coming to the very front after everything else tones down and taking over for the rest of the time with sweeter jasmine flowers peeking out for a moment every once in a lucky while and hiding between appearances. Smells like that car ride up there
and a hike through the woods. One of my favorite things I've ever smelled.

Jun
06
2014
megrim

This is a tricky one for me to review. As a 16 year old boy wasting time in a Meyers perfume department with some friends, I randomly stumbled across this, and it blew my mind.

Up until I first smelt the greasy, sweet, leathery goodness of Fahrenheit I'd always thought of perfumes as loud, overbearing things made for loud, overbearing women with tacky costume jewellery and shoulder pads - (growing up in the eighties didn't help with this).

But this was different. It sang to me. A lush and thrumming spicy-citrus opening, followed by what is still - 16 years later - my favourite drydown of any frag. It's warm, it's spicy, it's smoky - but with a wonderful, shimmering, soaring violet leaf accord to lift the entire experience and prevent it stumbling into 'old man tobacco' territory.

This is certainly a frag that evokes a reaction, for better or for worse. Certainly not for everybody. As a side note, when I asked my boyfriend to describe Fahrenheit in his own words, he stated - "Y'know the smell of the floor of a mechanics' workshop?, it's like they made a candy out of that smell". Oddly enough, I don't disagree with him, but I still love it to pieces.

Longevity for me is excellent, as is sillage.

Jun
03
2014
cmbathyal

This is the most versatile and unique scent I came across till now apart from Cartier roadster..yes it is dark and have gasoline vibe in the start only to be greeted by heavenly dry down:-)..hold on and u will see the beauty of this beast...star of my collection..nuff said;-).

zinski19901

Jun
02
2014
Ryanmmas26

I have a love,hate relationship with this fragrance. Reason being that this was 1 of the frags my step dad had in the late 80s early 90s and when he wore it it smelled really rich,masculine and had and it had an odd combination of smelling clean and dirty at the same time. On me all it just smells like a synthetic old man smell.lol... So with that said ive smelled this on other people and it smells great but on my skin the gasoline smell just doesnt mesh well and smells dated and slightly rancid to be honest. (And thats after a shower)

The performance on this however is TOP NOTCH ... The stuff lasts 12-16 hours and projects VERY WELL for the duration of the fragrance.

My personal rating on my skin id give this a 6 out of 10 !

But on my step dad the way it smelled id give it an 8 out of 10 ! Easy !!!

Jun
02
2014
Jack_Lumber

For those who have never had the opportunity to experience the (multiple) previous formulations of Fahrenheit, this latest blend would, I am sure, appear to be a quality and somewhat unique offering from Dior.

Don't get me wrong, I still love this fragrance, just not as much as I used to.
I don't think I personally got the chance to try to original release, however I have noticed that my last 3 bottles of this juice have become slightly different each time, and each time becoming less complex and less of a journey.

If you have remained faithful to a scent that you love, such as I have with Fahrenheit, it is greatly disappointing to see the "life" taken out of it for whatever reason. Whether it be in order to please the masses by removing any possible "offensive" or risky notes, or motivated by profit margins by reducing the quantity and quality of ingredients, or more likely a combination of the two, I feel it is not only a loss for the repeat long-term consumer, but eventually for Dior itself.

With so many scents being released seemingly every day, the market place is becoming increasingly competitive, and I feel that it is because of this continued reformulating of many of the fragrances that I once loved that I am beginning to lose my loyalty to certain houses and offering it to new ones.

I still love Fahrenheit, I am just not sure if I will purchase another bottle once the one I have is empty.

May
31
2014
loischanricky

I have both the original and the reformulated.
They are quite different according to my nose.

the reformulated (tested on the tester strip):
the smell of gasoline came out in 5 minutes.
the leather note came out after 40 minutes, and was combined with the gasoline note.
But it is a pity that this fragrance doesn't change a lot, all I can catch is that leather and gasoline notes combined together, then this combination slowly fades away after 3 hours.
It lasted about 6-8 hours on the strip.

the original (tested on the tester strip, on my skin and on my quilt)
the gasoline note came out right away after I sprayed some on the tester card, but after 15 mins I caught the bergamot, the cedar, the nutmeg, the lemon and some very little chamomile, the smell of gasoline disappeared and changed into different notes. (I think the gasoline smell is the first impression we get from Fahrenheit, but it's goal is to reach into a new level, that's why the gasoline note changed so fast)
after 3 hours I smelled a much tender scent which combined with the leather notes. I will describe the tender scent as floral note in men's fragrances, or the fresh scent you catch in a forest with many little flowers growing on the land.
after 12 hours, the smell changed again, this time it became a quasi-oriental fragrance. The sandalwood was quite obvious, along with the patchouli in the background. In the meantime, the leather note was still there (but not as loud as 12 hours before).
but it's very strange that when using it on my quilt, I smell sandalwood first, THEN comes the patchouli, but the leather note has gone.
When spraying it on my skin, the most obvious note in the base is white musk, while the sandalwood and patchouli relegate to the auxiliary, and the leather note has disappeared.

The reformulated is still a great one, if you are looking for a fragrance not so strong and masculine. I know someone can be frightened by the strong and unique smell of the original Fahrenheit.
But I have to say, the original one has more attitudes and changes quite a lot, and I love it a lot.

May
31
2014
JohnB2014

You may think its a winter fragrance but its not: Ver manly, nice feeling about it, a mixture of leather & floral.Wow! This is a classic.

10/10.

May
30
2014
chris.kragel

Quite a unique fragrance, and a bit of an acquired scent.
To me, it smells of leather, tobacco, and smoke. How one fragrance can manage all of this is beyond me, but Dior pulls off yet another masterpiece.
This fragrance is quite different, both in its wearability and quality.
When you spray it on, you must keep an open mind about how it projects. Think- leather jackets, cigarettes, and rock stars. It literally epitomizes the rock star life of sex, booze, and rock and roll!
It dwells on the skin for a long time, with good projection to anyone around. You will definitely get noticed wearing this- perhaps in a good way...perhaps in a bad way.

Projection- 7/10 (It will be smelled by anyone within 6 foot)
Longevity- 9/10 (8+ hours)
Versatility- 5/10 (Limited use- dates, parties, casual wear)
Overall smell- 8/10 (Unique as hell! Quite the attention grabber, and strangely sensual to women)

26

beatrix75

THE BEST MALE FRAG EVER ROMANTIC SEXY STRONG EXCEPTIONAL !!!!MY LOVE HAVE THIS ONE

May
26
2014
Jerry Can

I remember this when it was launched. I absolutely loved it and wore it for several years. Reminded me of Parma violets. But masculine (although women admitted to wearing it). Complex too. The current scent is a poor impostor, and had I not tried this again recently in Debenhams (a retailer of impeccable repute) I would have discarded it as a fake. It is a sham. It should have been renamed, because it is not the Fahrenheit I knew. It did not improve in the dry down. This must be the most detrimentally affected reformulation I have encountered. Awful. And it does smell of petrol too.

UPDATE 5th September 2015
Tried this again having noticed it worn on another on whom it smelled like the Fahrenheit I once knew. It seemed noticeably better than the bottle sampled six months ago, and the dry down closer to my original memory of it. But to be absolutely clear, this is still not remotely the same as the original. Makes me wonder what is going on at Dior. That perhaps they are listening to feedback and responding to it? Evidently there would seem to be some variability across batches. At least I am slightly more encouraged, and will explore this scent again before too long.

UPDATE 11th December 2015
It is not the EdT my heart remembers and yearns for. For now, I just accept that the current version is what it is: of sufficient appeal for me to rekindle what was once an inseparable affection. And evidently that affection still runs deep to this day. So after too long an hiatus, once again I am engaged with this ongoing (if controversial) story that is Dior's finest ever offering.

07
2014
lee_maccuckoo

So... this one was quite an enjoyable surprise for me. Just tried it this evening at a local fragrance store and I'm on my way to get a bottle. The thing about the oil/ gasoline opening note is true, and I must say I enjoyed the trick; however, the first thing that came to my mind was my uncle's old typography workshop and the smell of some kind of lub or grease he used to do the maintenance of those heavy machines. Also, reminiscences of the local garage... well, the best thing about Fahrenheit is that this first note lasts only enough to set the scene.

The heart, however, turns into something greenish, herbal, rich...I must confess that Fahrenheit in fact lived up to all the expectations I had when I decided to blind buy VC&A's Tsar, a fragrance I'm still struggling to fully appreciate (perhaps when winter comes...).

In a nutshell, Dior's Fahrenheit pays tribute to the tongue-in-cheek side of rock'n'roll: leather jackets, booze and cigarretes (that is definitely a smokers' scent) and a classic bike ride on the road. Can't wait to put my hands on that!

Apr
01
2014
JJH1966

I'm pretty sure that petroleum smell everyone is talking about is caused by Iso-E Super, a synthetic aroma molecule used heavily in Fahrenheit. Iso-E Super by itself doesn't have much of an odor, but reacts to the wearer's body chemistry and can smell smokey, woody or even a bit like petroleum.

If you're interested in the effects of Iso-E Super on you, try Escentric Molecules "Molecule 01" which is a single note fragrance with only Iso-E Super.

Apr

insectatribe01

jfr1974

In the mid 90s I was one of those young men who literally swam in this juice. For a while even it was my signature scent until I discovered JPG Le Male in the late 90s. Today I tried for the first time in almost 20 years expecting to be transported back to my clubbing youth by this scent I so loved. Don't know why I had this sudden urge to revisit.

It wasn't a complete let down - however for the first 20mins all I could smell was that petrol/rubber note in a much sharper way than I ever remembered. It could just be me; I could have changed. I now enjoy more powdery renditions of rubber e.g. Midnight in Paris. The rubber screamed so hard in fahrenheit. It eventually gave way to the more floral/woody/spicy base I remember. That was more pleasant. So I'm slightly disappointed. May be it wasn't the right time to spray; who knows?

It's still a fine fragrance - so unique. Young folk give this a try.

Grottola

Update:

Mar
14
2014
lucasdeus94

What can I say about this legend that hasn't been said?

I just can say that after years buying and trying hundreds of colognes, I finally found my signature scent. I can use this one in any ocasion, day or night, cold or hot (though not extremelly hot - 32c and under) weather. And this scent is really what I want to smell and be recognized for.

Before I start my review, I want to say something about that vintage-reformulation thread: yeah, there is a difference. But a small difference.
The vintage one that I had (a 1995 batch) lasts and projects a bit more, and has some some strong earthy feeling that I can't find on my reformulated (2013 batch) one. I've tested dozens of bottles and batches, and I concluded that this claim that the vintage is way better than the reformulated is only a purist thing. The reformulated one still is a masterpiece and has awesome longevity and projection. I just hope that a future reformulation don't mess up with this masterpiece. Trust me, folks: the reformulated one is very close to the vintage one. So, if you can find a vintage bottle easily and for a good price, buy it, but if you can't, grab a bottle of the reformulated one. It will give you almost the same scent and performance of the vintage and the same feel of wearing the masterpiece of cologne that Fahrenheit is.

Well, now I can start my review.

Fahrenheit is a scent that has three distinct fases, which the base is almost nothing like the opening. The opening is close to the heart that is close to the base. The transitions on this one are quick and huge.
It opens up with a petrol-like note that everyone knows and gones away within some minutes, and a fresh mandarin, chamomille and bergamot, with the violet leaf in the background, all of that with a mineral oily feeling. But it fades away very quick, about 30min after you sprayed it on your skin, and then it becomes floral with hints of leather and spices. The violet leaf is a main player here, with the honysuckle, lily-of-the-valley and jasmin doing the floral heart of this beauty. The nutmeg does and great job of balancing the florals and the leather/vetiver combo on the background does a great job of keeping the fragrance bold and masculine. There is some hints of the oily-petrol note in the heart of the fragrance. After 2 hours of the floral heart, we are going to enter the base. The base is a purely a woody and earthy leather scent with a hint of spices. The leather is by far the main player here, with vetiver and cedar in the background and amber to give a small hint of sweetness (mineral, not suggary-like) to balanceate the formula, also with the musk to give an animalic and rusty feel. The petrol and floral notes doesn' t exists no more and it will stay this way until the end of the fragrance. So, it is a fragrance that the three stages are very different and close to each other. The smell that you have on your skin after 5 hours of application is totally different from the smell of the smell that you have on your skin after 5min of application. It is a work of genius. Pure art and passion.

I use it with six sprays (one on the chest, two on the neck e one on each wrist).

Scent: 10/10 (Pure work of art. Timeless and unique. Masterpiece.)
Longevity: 9,5/10 (8 to 12 hours).
Projection: 9 (Projects heavy in the first 2 hours, then more 2-3 hours of moderate projection and it becomes skin.)
Sillage: 8 (Announces your entrance and when you leave the room, your smell will remain there for a good time.)
Versatility: 9/10 (Any ocasion, anywhere. But it is not made for extreme heat.)
Compliments: 9/10 (Although I never got a compliment gallore with this one, all of the compliments were higly positive. This is a seductive and sexy fragrance.)
Overall: 10/10 (I really cannot see myself giving less than 10 for this masterpiece. This is a gift to the world of the fragrances.)

It is a timeless work of pure genius, class and art, that is totally unique after more than 25 years of market. Thank you Dior for this staple in any collector's arsenal. Maurice Roger and Jean-Louis Sieuzac, you will have my eternal respect and grattitude for making this daring and unique scent.

Mar
14
2014
hasanbenvidi

. . . .

Mar
08
2014
SheAlwaysSmellsGood

When a man or a woman walks into the room wearing this scent, my head immediately turns, my eyes close, and I just enjoy it. This is one of my most favorite scents of all time. When I was in my early 20s, it always smelled like leather and cucumbers to me. I was at a bar not too long ago and a few girlfriends were standing outside and the wind blew ever so lightly and I said, "Someone is wearing Fahrenheit!" It happened to be my female friend and it worked so good on her. I will never stop enjoying this scent so long as they don't change a thing!

07
2014
DSun

I know a few people who like the smell of petrol aka gasoline. A few. Fahrenheit was made for those people. Evidently, the House of Dior wanted to innovate by mixing non-conventional ingredients. This is just my opinion, but they failed.

Update: I just found out what I had been reviewing is a reformulation. Now, I'm wondering if the original was really better. 2014-06-15.

Update: Ok, I smelled the vintage and it's just harsh. I read on somebody else's blog that it's supposed to be what fire would smell like if fire indeed had a smell. I'll just have to shake my head on that. Almighty Time's verdict is that Fahrenheit is a classic. I'll abide by that verdict, but I don't have to agree with it.

Mar
03
2014
Kuggi

One of the best male fragrances ever made.
Fahrenheit is a legend and it still smells too go to be true.

To those of you who blame this perfume because of the reformulation:

Actually, there is no big difference between the original version and the newest version.
If you dont believe it, then ask any perfumer about the differences between them.
The vintage version smells deeper and more edged, but the newest version is more elegant.
As I said, there is no big difference.
People, that claim the newest version has nothing to do with the vintage Fahrenheit, have no idea.

I hear they change the formula, but the aroma is still the same to me.

Juiceman 0331

1-31-2014
Believe it or not, my first cologne at the age of 14 was Fahrenheit. For some reason my dad gave it to me back in the mid ninetees.
Why Fahrenheit for a 14 yr old boy? I don't know what my dad was thinking.
I loved Fahrenheit at that young age and I will never forget the smell. It's just like your first girlfriend, you'll never forget her.

I am now 31yrs old and me and my wife just started collecting colognes/perfumes again about a year ago and me and my wife have close to 100 perfumes in our closet, but never purchased Fahrenheit.
For years I always had that question of why my dad gave me Fahrenheit when it was suited for him and not for me.
I will be purchasing one tomorrow and I have never been excited like this with all my past purchases.
I am hoping that Fahrenheit is still the same one I remember as my first cologne or atleast very close to it.


UPDATE: 2/11/14
So, I got my Fahrenheit along with Green Irish Tweed.
I was so excited that once the salesperson handed me my bag, I didn't reach for my first Creed, but for my Fahrenheit and opened it.
After 17 years of not holding this bottle, I sprayed 3 on my neck and one on each elbow pit and the first person that came into my mind was the person that gave me my first cologne, my first Fahrenheit.... my dad.

Yes, I can tell the difference with the reformulated that I bought and it doesn't last as long. But It is still a great cologne and I will always have a stock, because just looking at the bottle reminds me of my dad.

I finally know the answer why my dad gave me Fahrenheit when I was only 14 yrs old... He has a great taste when it comes to colognes and he wanted me to have the best during that time.

This cologne will always have a sentimental value to me, it will always remind me of my dad.
Because of the Fahrenheit you gave me when I was 14, I am now a collector. I wish you're here with me so both of us can go to a mall and shop for colognes together. We will max out all our credit cards in one day.
Thank you so much dad. I love you and I miss you so much... = (


My overall rating 9/10

31
2014
muncierobson

I LOVE this

First smelt it in 1988 aged 6 when walking through a department store in Singapore, and the over eager sales assistants were dousing everyone in it! I was 6 then! And covered in a cloud of mans perfume that smelt like sweets (parma violets are a fav)!

I am considerably older now and it still makes that same impression! It is truly unique, Fahrenheit smells like nothing else, though many attempts have been been to make something smell like Fahrenheit!

The violet dominates for me. It's sweet, sexy and masculine. It's definitely a perfume and I hardly notice any gasoline note... It is instantly recognisable and while the reviews on here are mixed, I've only had positive feedback!

I could wear it all year round but I guess it's character suits relaxed informal occasions. Strong sillage and longevity though it never smells harsh to me and I'm quite generous with my applications! The mandarin keeps it fresh for mild weather and the woods and spices keep it warm for autumn/winter!

I've changed quite dramatically since 1988 but my love of Fahrenheit remains! It still smells fresh today and is poles apart from the generic 'old man' citrus aromatics (which I've started to enjoy also since hit 30 lol)!

I wrote a piece about this fragrance earlier when it didn't appeal to me much.. it was funny and still is.. but in the end, it was inaccurate.. I've left it up so I can wallow in the shame of the arrogance of my ignorance :).. but hey, nobody's perfect, we all make mistakes.. and so, I've put up my new and reviewed feelings on Dior Fahrenheit:

Fahrenheit.. is.. a classic... it really is.. It hits masculinity in exactly the right way.. Its not like those alpha male types you see in the club.. like condensed blobs of fear, pushing and shoving their way around the place.. too scared to feel you, too scared to get to know you, to scared to let you in... no.. Fahrenheit has a smooth sensuality to it, yet it is intensely masculine..

It flows to every corner of your being.. to every crevice.. into every cell.. and from there it explodes like a thousand sparks of light invigorating you, leaving you feeling satisfied and content.. stronger than before...

A great scent.. Masculine.. Sophisticated yet primal.. Classic.. very nice..

Jan
08
2014
jht4060

The most distinctive and commented-upon note in Fahrenheit is the gasoline-like note that is particularly strong at the start. I rather like the note (and I love Fahrenheit), but apparently some people loathe it or can't smell it at all. I decided to figure out what was responsible, and it was not easy.

After much reading and sampling of scents I can buy on-line, I have concluded that this gasoline-kerosene note is the molecule styrene (produced naturally in the resin of the trees Liquidambar orientalis and Liquidambar styraciflua). The distilled oil from this resin is usually called styrax or storax, and has some of the scent character of benzoin, which confusingly comes from the tree Styrax benzoin (despite the name it is in a different order of plants from Liquidambar - a rather distant relative, about as related as humans and elephants). Unlike benzoin, styrax can have a prominent gasoline-like note from styrene.

Here is a quote from distiller Steffen Arctander:

"Steam distilled styrax oil is a pale yellow to almost water-white, viscous liquid with an odor that is very rich, balsamic-sweet, floral and somewhat spicy, reminiscent of lilac, hyacinth, etc. although it has a distinct topnote of hydro-carbon character, unpleasant and actually not wanted. The topnote can be disposed of by leaving out the heads of the steam distillate but, on the other hand, many customers expect this styrene note and it also mellows in to a great extent after some time."

Styrax oils that I obtained from two different sources have the exact Fahrenheit top note to my nose. Either Dior adds pure styrene to Fahrenheit or they use a styrax oil with the styrene deliberately left in.

By the way, styrene is known to most people because it is the monomer component of the plastic polystyrene (and its foamed variant styrofoam). It isn't healthy in large amounts, such as you'd get if you used it as a solvent in a factory, but in small amounts it is probably harmless. It was originally made from styrax resin (hence the name styrene) but is much more cheaply made synthetically from petroleum these days.

Jan
05
2014
Adler

A very nice cologne, but so different from what I've come to expect. Got my first bottle recently.

You spray it, and there's an interesting tug-of war between two very different olfactory combinations.

On one hand, you have the industrial, gasoline, asphalt, burnt-rubber smell.

But on the other, more dominant hand, you have a very fresh smell. It's aquatic, fruity, and somewhat cool. I get melon, cucumber, honeysuckle, jasmine. People mention citrus, but I notice little to none.

Amber and Tonka are inevitable for a cologne like this. Throw in some sandalwood and a tiny bit of cedar and musk, and boom.

All of it bound together with the (pleasantly) overwhelming and versatile smell of leather, and you have a very wearable fragrance. What's strange is that industrial petrol smell comes and goes.

-Scent 8/10
-Sillage/Projection 7/10
-Longevity 7/10

Overall a good cologne. Versatile, can be worn by pretty much any age or type of man. My only qualms are that after reading so much about it, I had slightly higher hopes than an A- cologne. I can only assume that the pre-reforumlated variety was perfection in a bottle.

Used in moderation, it can be fresh and subtle, good for even a mild summer day. A few small spurts and you have an aquatic, fruity cologne that could be worn to work. If you're a bit more liberal with atomizer, it's more seductive as the motor oil and tarry hot asphalt come out.

I guess it could be described as eating fruit salad at a gas station, sitting in a convertible muscle car with Italian leather seats, and a bouquet of assorted flowers for your wife in the seat beside you.

rodolfo

Simply put, this is the smell of Masculinity!
Fahrenheit transcends what a perfume can be. It evokes images to the mind.

Life is not as easy as you thought it would be. You've learned by now that it can be cruel and scary, and if you let it, it will hit you very hard and keep you on your knees.
So what's it gonna be?
Will you lie down and cry like a pussy?
Or will you stand up and fight like a beast?
Are you man enough? Can you handle it?
That's what Fahrenheit is asking in your face!
It's the inner fight with yourself. It's like ceasing to be a boy and becoming a man that's in control of his own life.
Now you're ready to take on the world.
That's how I feel when I wear this masterpiece.

Now, performance wise, this is a monster: with one full spray it radiates far from me and can even fill a room sometimes. It lasts until the other day too. You're gonna have a hard time putting on another cologne the next day, cause it lingers.
Most ladies find this super sexy. Compliments galore.
Even if some girl doesn't like the way it smells on you(which is rare), who cares? You're the man and you don't need permission from anybody to smell badass. She'll love it eventually, you'll see.

Projection: 5/5
Longevity: 5/5
Scent: 5/5
Versatility: 3/5
Compliments: Almost always.
Extreme Compliments: Of course!

The only mature fragrance that is still very modern. Timeless!

Overall: 5/5

Dec
06
2013
nero77

In 1988 Dior decided to break the mould in terms of men's fragrances and decided to go in a different direction, by turning the established system on it's head. What they managed to create was something entirely unique (even today). They succeeded in creating a truly remarkable and very masculine floral (by using violet, nutmeg, carnation, and a lot of leather).

The result? Something which smells beautifully modern even today. In a word - timeless.

I believe that years later Dior would turn the world of male perfumes on it's head for a second time (with their metrosexual floral leather release 'Dior Homme'). However for many people, this is considered their best masculine and I think it's one of the most unique designer masculine fragrances ever created.

Instead of the Leather-Iris combination used in Dior Homme, here it's Leather and Violet, a pairing which gives off what many people term "sweet motor oil".

Before actually wearing this on my skin, I tried the luxury 'soap' of this for years, never finally wearing the fragrance itself until now. To me this can't be categorised purely by a "gasoline" smell (and I happen to like the smell of petrol). To me, this fragrance smells like an incredibly clean version of petroleum. Imagine a mechanic who after working a long day with the car grease and motor oil, then decided to take a really good bath or shower with luxury, high-quality soap. After he's finished, he smells clean and fragrant, but the original petrol note is under all the soap, and because of this, now starts to smell "clean" as well. Of course this is also a perfectly blended fragrance, and you'll struggle to put your finger on why exactly this smells as good as it does. The combination of violet leaf, leather, nutmeg, musk, geranium, lavender and carnation makes this extremely masculine. However it could be worn very well by a woman because it's also sweet at the same time. It's addictive!

I think the marketing concept of Fahrenheit was a perfume of contrasts. Specifically Hot and Cold, or "Fire and Ice". Fahrenheit is a measurement of temperature, and as a result applies to burning, boiling heat and also icy cold. As an olfactory sensation, Fahrenheit straddles the line between these two extremes, and does it beautifully.

I will say that this smells just as modern as it ever did 25 years ago, and could easily be released today and go on to be a number one hit. It's unique, nothing out there smells like it. It's not like Cool Water (also released in 1988), which went on to spawn the aquatic craze of the 1990's, and as a result is starting to smell a little dated by today's standards.

This has lost none of it's originality. It is well worth it's reputation. I believe that it can be worn by almost anyone and in any season. It needs no introduction. It is what it is (even in our time)... original, unique, & unmistakably beautiful!

Dec
03

CozyCat

I'm making my fiancee get this, and I'd love this to be his signature.

Oct
31
2013
Anon_gibs

Dirty motor oil. Gasoline. Worn leather. Draped over memories of air freshener Is there a place in your wardrobe for such a scent? Quite possibly...

This combination of notes yields a very masculine smell. Its certainly. Not for everyday wear nor for most occasions. Its very muddled n likely the " dirtiest" frag on the mArket since its creation. The only thing ive smelled that even comes close is polo blAck. But it smells more of tires... Much cleaner.

This juice has steadily stood the test of time but likely has a very particular following. Its not an alluring or versatile scent. It certainly will not appeal to those that tend to enjoy citrus, green, woody or fresh frags. Its very dark n dank... Greasy smelling. Especially for first hour then it does soften to a degree...

I am not hating on this juice but suffice it to say it isnt my fav. If ur looking for leathery scents there are a couple of others that are much nicer n certainly more forgiving.

As a collector, all of us have this in the mix but it is not a " go to" kind of frag at all.

To be frank, i find it dark n depressing... Not something i enjoy. But, as I always say... Each frag smells differently on each of us... This is just my humble impression of the stuff!!!

Enjoy!!! Ciao!

31

ed

blackw0lfx

really nice. to me it kinda reminded me of being outside in the snow with a wood fire going. i get a musky leather with lavender jasmine nutmeg and cedar. its got some sweetness to it. i can kinda get a grease vibe from it. i imagine a guy working in a shop who puts on his leather coat and starts a fire in the snow. a strong man of few words. a sweet man though. i wish it was a little fruity and then i would totally wear it. like if it had some plum and rose or something.

Oct
11
2013
aqua_de_la_vita

After many years later, I finally purchased my second bottle of Fahrenheit. Everything about the first spray came back to me. The similarity to petroleum comes from the voliet which dies out after vvs a couple of minutes
When the frag dries back, it continues to stay strong with the base notes of leather and a very strong note of violet leaf.
I also find this cologne a very rooty/woodsy base from nutmeg and cedar with a faint aroma of lavender/ carnation giving this frag the most distinguished frag that is out there.
Longevity is like most Dior frag's...superb !!!!
Sillage is the same...EXCELLENT.

Overall thoughts

Fahrenheit is still being produced and is still being stocked on stores selves as well all the attention on the HATE or LOVE of this frag is like a CLASSIC MOVIE....some like it and some just don't. The allure of this frag is a testimonial to this frag.

When I first purchased my first bottle I didn't understand why everyone was going crazy buying this frag. My first purchase was more of reaction of being part of that Fahrenheit Club. Now, over 20yrs later I have had many frag and I consider Dior's Fahrenheit as a real unique frag that can not be mistaken. I have always said that a good fragrance will last over 8hrs...Fahrenheit surpasses that.

Oct
09
2013
mandaryn

As I read the other reviews I'm sensing that the current formulation of this has gone to shit, and that breaks my heart. My mostly empty bottle must have been bought at least 15 years ago (not kidding), and it's beautiful, and to think that I might never be able to replace it is disappointing because NOTHING is this unique anymore (well...I have a bottle of BVLGARI BLACK that might argue the point) and I mourn the loss of good fragrance for the sake of making sure that 0.3% of the population don't get a sensitizing reaction. For those folks, no offense, but FRAGRANCE IS NOT YOUR THING. So please quit bitching and let the rest of us enjoy it the way it was meant to be.......ruined my f'n day......

Oct
06
2013
mandaryn

The first fragrance I bought for myself. Few scents are crafted this well, as each of the notes are beautifully preserved throughout the day. It was what I wore when I was 17. My last bottle sat 1/3 full, neglected for quite some time. Today I pulled it out and sprayed some on my arm; it's moved back up to the front of the shelf. For those that like this one I believe it has an almost narcotic allure. For those that don't...try it again. In a time when fine fragrances are a dime a dozen, this was a master stroke.

06
2013
burgundyaltima

Don't believe the hype!..TRY BEFORE U BUY!!..This put me in a bad mood. lol at first spray it didn't smell too bad but as it dried down I couldn't wait to get home and scrub this off.... definitely unique, very potent, and mature. ONE spray was too much for me! the scent is very overwhelming...smells like flowers doused in gasoline..im also getting a Vicks vabor rub smell in the dry down...lasts forever...this would be perfect in colder weather...just not my style .PASS!

Oct
02
2013
lgbailey86

The difference between liking this fragrance or not is the same as preferring a Camembert to a Brie. The Brie is simpler and has appeal to a wider variety of people. But those that appreciate the depth and complexities of the Camembert that some find offensive understand its magnificence. One of the most addictive scents in production. Orange sun setting into gasoline and violet leaf sea and all melting over leather.
More than any other scent I've put my nose on, this is a try before buy situation.
I love it. But some people certainly wont. It does have some very clean aspects in the mid but the open is fairly dirty, which again, I love. But not everyone will.
Also, the new formulation may not be as intoxicatingly dirty and interesting as the original, but the reformulation in no way ruined this scent - definitely still stands out in an amazing way.

Sep
15
2013
pjd1234

Fahrenheit a classic its been around for ages and a staple for a reason. Fahrenheit and cool water were my first perfumes back when I was 10 years old lol I remember over applying fahrenheit maybe 6 sprays and fill up the room and the scent trail is enormous you can smell from afar. Fahrenheit is not a compliment getter I believe its a love or hate scent in my experience compliments are a 50/50 some like it some dont but as for me I love it as my motto with perfumes I wear my scent to please me not to please you so if you dont like it PISS OFF. The scent is pretty easy to describe the over all scent as I describe it is an orange or mandarin soaked in gasoline or diesel fuel I mean that in a very good way the violet leaf is prominent all way through with citruses making that mandarin orange soaked in gasoline vibe but as the scent ages it mellows down to an orangey citrus for me its a linear scent it does evolve just a little bit but very straight forward you will get that orange soaked in gasoline of a vibe til the end of the scent. Overall all its a warm unique scent. I use it all year around just adjust how much you spray overall a very warm and conforting scent definitely one of the timeless classics.

longevity 9/10 easily 8-12 hours this one last for a long time

sillage/projection 10/10 Fahrenheit projects very strong and to be honest offensive if not used properly so easy on the trigger I believe projection varies on skin but overall monster in projection.

uniqueness 9/10 very unique very original nothing else like it in my opinion the first of its kind.

overall smell 9/10 high remarks for me on this one a timeless classic for me indeed Fahrenheit is a scent that I will always have in my collection.

price vs quality 9/10 200ml for 100 usd retail is quite a very good deal and a steal ofcoarse also available online fo much less. fairly priced for its quality of juice.

versatility all year for me hot, cold, humid days it stands out. overall I really appreciate dior having this masterpiece running throughout the years its a keeper I don't understand some of the manufacturers like Gucci discontinued pour home 1 or ysl abandoning m7 and opium and even d&g ruining the original pour homme if dior can do it with Fahrenheit why cant they.

2013
hgonzalez

I don't know what formulation have (i purchased in 2011 aprox). It's a nice, manly, strong and unsual scent.

PROS:
- It's a classic.
- Very different (in a good way) to the other fragrances.
- Projects and last a lot.
- Masculine

CONS:
- If over apply, can offend to somebody

For me, it's a must have. Definitly worth the try.

15
2013
petrus

Magnificence pour soire d't au bord de la mer. (Vintage)

Senteur 10/10 Comme tous les grands parfums, Fahrenheit mrite un usage appropri qui ne soit pas quotidien sinon, il risque de fatiguer. Pour ma part, a a t ma signature pendant prs de 13 ans, de 1989 2002. Et oui, la fin, il m'a fatigu.
Ce parfum exprime sa splendeur le soir, en t, de prfrence au bord de la mer. C'est ainsi que je fis sa rencontre pour ma part par un chantillon, et quel surprise ! Ce parfum sent une plante marine odorifante qu'on trouve au bord de l'Atlantique et sa senteur se marie parfaitement l'odeur de la mer, au bord de la plage, en t : c'est l qu'il dveloppe sa magnificence, c'est l qu'il mrite sa note de 10/10. L'autre usage adquat serait plutt en hiver de jour, mais sa note serait un peu infrieure.

Sillage 2/2 Parfait.

Longvit 2/2. Plus de 6 heures facilement.

Masculinit 2/2 Masculinit rayonnante, crasante, charmeuse, sensuelle, sexuelle, crbrale, complte. Trop complte pour un usage quotidien.

Evolution 4/4 Se marie avec votre peau. Vous faites corps avec lui, il vous enveloppe de son cuir raffin.

TOTAL 20/20 Chef d'oeuvre

The sample on my right is just a very weak woody leather with little projection. RIP Fahrenheit.

livio.marucci

This is the "Leather Perfume"! It smells like my black leather jacket... It is extremely masculine, the nutmegs and amber notes give him a hot sensation... but you can still feel the freezing notes of musk and violet leaf... it is the dichotomy Dior mention on their commercials... hot and cold... air and earth... water and fire... And the Leather of this is the best... it would be great for leather or bikers fetichists ... The fixation is outstanding and it has a long projection...
If there is a ultimate Rocker this is the perfume he would wear...
Marvelous...

23
2013
Guilherme Fernandes

Fahrenheit is the best night-time fragrance!!!

Fahrenheit is powerful, modern, sexy, intriguing, smells expensive and very manly.

It opens with the mysterious and powerful fuel note and goes almost 1 hour with this.

After 1 hours, Fahrenheit calms down and become more woody, spicy, leather and a little floral.

obs: if you want a long time longevity (more than 12 hours), you can spray more than once... but beware to do not overspray!

Fragrncia/Fragrance: 9/10
Fixao/ Longevity: 9/10 (7-8 hours)
Projeo/ Sillage: 10/10 (It has an awesome sillage- beast mode for 3 hours easily)
Versatilidade/ Versatillity: 7/10
Try/ Buy/ Pass: Try

Fahrenheit a melhor fragrncia noturna!!!

Fahrenheit poderoso, moderno, sexy, intrigante, cheira caro e muito masculino.

Ele abre com a misteriosa e poderosa nota de combustvel e segue por quase 1 hora com ela.

Depois de 1 hora, Fahrenheit "se acalma" e se torna mais amadeirado, especiado, notas de couro e um pouco floral.

obs: se voc deseja uma grande fixao (mais de 12 horas), voc pode aplicar mais de 1 spray... mas cuidado para no exagerar!!

Aug
22
2013
hedward

- Nutmeg violet -

Starts with a blast of ber masculine gasoline and violet leaf that quickly dries down into a weird leather grass combo that pulsates with a major sillage for 4-5h. Finally after the confusing green heart stops pumping a rather sweet amber tonka combo pairs up with the leather conjuring a TREMENDOUS yet feminine scent that stays close to skin for a few more hours.

This is like the counterpart of TM's Angel. Angel starts with feminine berries and dries down to spicy and masculine dark chocolate. Fahrenheit in turn opens with grass and gasoline but ends up being sweet leather and soft as a babys butt. In other words sure Fahrenheit could be labeled unisex just like Angel.

Very very unique, great longevity, proper sillage, mature, timeless yet a bit outdated, great quality as expected from Dior. I wanted to compare this with F Absolute (which due to incense is a winner for me) but they are both absolutely genial in their own league so that wont be necessary.

Aug
16
2013
Houdini4

Fahrenheit and I have a long history...Love it now as much as I did when I first encountered its warmth. It was 1989 and it was my friends dads...been hooked ever since. I don't currently own a bottle simply because it is very powerful stuff and it's nice to have a break every now and again.
I get a lot of sweet violet and vetiver from it...strong & beautiful and about to get revisited by me... Might try the aqua one?
It will always be a favourite of mine. A true classic and no mistake.

Had never smelled anything like it and it blew me away. for some reason i still remember thinking it smelled like fresh cut cucumber which in the hot indian summer felt wonderfully cool. I havent had a bottle of this in a while and i think I should get one again. If you havent smelled this you are doing your nose an injustice. 9/10

Amparo Noir

Fahrenheit is truly one of a kind fragrance. Bold and exceptionally unique, above all, it's original. The current formulation is woodier while the vintage is far greener and grassier with distinct petroleum-gasoline note.

All n all, I still love the latest formulation, the only downfall is, it doesnt last long, max 2 - 3 hours.

Jul
30
2013
Jose Marcos

I first sampled Dior fahrenheit when I was much younger ;) and thought it was too strong and the gasoline feeling was beyond me. then Last year I bought ferrari Uomo and thought itreminded me fo DF a lot, and the gasoline was there just to remind me. I gave FU up but fahrenheit kept buzzzing in my mind until I saw a very good price and for a 200ml bottle. I didn't waste any time and ordered it. and today, much for my surprise, the huge bottle arrived and it brought good news also: the gasoline smell is just an effect from many notes and it is not as strong as I remembered it to be. Aqua F is indeed Fahrenheit+citrus. This reformulation was made September 2012, so it seems weaker only in strengh, potency for it still smells the same. the gas note is reduced to a minimum and I can sense the floral bouquet in the background, lilly, jasmim, carnation and even the pollen honeysuckle. The cirus accord was present in the opening but very briefly. And then LEATHER, ah soft leather, the bit I miss in Aqua, and some woods attesting it is a male scent. Yes, it is as if a man after finished his lown started to pick some flowers for his beloved, using his own hands the green juices from dayses and pollen mixed with his own scent... after some sort of impact work, and some minor fumes from the lownmower, of course. Has it bacome more refined and recollected or was I who came to a time in which I can really apprecaite Dior Fahrenheit with body and soul?

Ferrari Uomo does come very close to DF, less complex and thinner without the refined manners DF possesses.

2013
Ovrnightr

I'm really loving this one. After falling in love with DHI and Sport, I had to give is one a shot, and it's paid off. I have to admit, when I left Sephora and tested it out in the car for the ride home, I neatly tucked away the receipt thinking I'd be returning it. It was just so strange to me, floral petroleum and leather filled the air. After two days of diligent experimentation, however, I'm, like I said, REALLY loving this one. It's just a totally unique fragrance from what's on offer from today's releases. It's not sporty, it's not powdery, it's animalic and it's bold. It's fun to smell like this. I highly recommend giving this a try. It's really a beautiful composition, and I have to say I totally dig the fossil fuel edginess this imparts.

9.5/10

This fragrance is old fashioned, but in a powerful, "I know who I am " kind of way. Men that wear this are leaders, not followers. Its instantly recognisable, traditional, and mmmmm lovely.

I never tire of this one. It wont go in and out of fashion, it smells good - always has and always will.

LookOut

The opening of this scent is absolutely revolting for me, all I smell is the leather/petrol smell.

Too bad about the opening. Even when I'm more mature I probably still won't buy it. But who knows, maybe then the petrol/leather smell won't bug me anymore ...

Oh well, flankers here we go! :p

2013
Ichariot

Fahrenheit is a masculine scent. Too bad I cannot let my imagination flow while smelling it since it always reminds me so strongly of few people I know (that use it).

I don't see it fit boys, it's for men. This indeed reminds me of an older man chopping wood beside a summer cottage, smelling like fahrenheit. Or a rough sailor with tanned skin and already white hair. There's something really comforting about the smell. It makes you feel like you can rely on the guy wearing it.

I don't see it as a club soda or a player juice. It's definately a scent for older and mature men.

That's just me though, you might think otherwise so go test it out, it's worth checking nevertheless!

Jun
05
2013
hornetz

The days of the powerhouse era are long gone replaced by aquatics and fruity zesty lighter colognes. Fahrenheit was a different breed, it set out to conquer everything in its path not giving a care what any one thought. The weird chamomile petroleum note does put you off but it has its way of redeeming itself. Is this cologne good; Yes its great, it's a classic. However, it's not relevant for todays standards and reformulations has wrecked its DNA making it just a name to sell. If you find an older version hold on to it, otherwise try out the new Fahrenheit line up that is more wearable these days. It's a very unique fragrance that I appreciate yet can not wear.

30
2013
anna.dkr5

I've just read an article about chamomile on this site, and I quote:

"One of the perfumes where chamomile note dominates the composition is certainly Diors iconic Fahrenheit for men. Launched in late eighties, this deep and masculine fragrance still captivates our attention, spreading the heady soul of chamomile right from the top notes. Chamomile note lends to this fragrance its distinctive petroleum hint, which can be felt in the very opening."

Author: Marina Milojevi (Mary)
Fragrantica Writer, Translator & Editor


I had no idea the potroleum smell was the chamomile...
What do you guys think?

May
30
2013
juan carlos.henriquez

elixir magico de virilidad y seduccion, hay mujeres q aman oler farenheit en un hombre, huele a violeta cuero y testosterona, huele a noche y a sexo, farenheit para mi seria la mejor colonia de todos los tiempos para hombres.
Farenheit la octava maravilla del mundo.

only people i can see wearing this are those who belong to a biker gang. really strong leather smell that mixes with the green notes in this to make a very strong, overly masculine fragrance that i think is both too mature for anyone under 35 and simply smells bad

May
21
2013
Bandit

That's so funny: I had a strip with Fahrenheit in my very beautiful vegan fake leather bag and now it even smells like a real leather bag (before it had a nasty smell). Now, that's what I call a leather scent!

Still on the fence about adding it to the collection: Do I need it? As a collector I do, as a perfume wearer I'm not sure: It smells so familiar, a little too cold and a little too ... ? I guess, it wouldn't get worn too often.

I'd say, if you're a male or tend to lean towards this gender, you have to have it. No collection is complete without this beauty.

May
17
2013
NickE ReauX

Oooh not much to say except I love it to death .. always always gonna wear it although it's Throne is in danger of being stolen by Fahrenheit Absolute. I found this at a time when I thought if I smelled one more person wearing Ck Eternity ( or the millions of others that smelled just like it ) I would shriek and claw my face. On a somber note.. I still have a vial of Very Original Fahrenheit and I'm sad to note the new stuff has been reformulated..doesn't change my love but it's a love now tinged with nostalgia and a slight melancholy..like remembering how you once loved an ex.

May
13
2013
Ricks44

Read about this on here and saw it recommended, tried it in stores and never got anything from it. Until I decided one day to spray on my skin and leave.... About 40 minutes after the initial spray... I got a gentle, warm, masculine scent. I was sold, bought it not long after. Every time I smell this scent, i'm reminded of the quality. It knows what it is and it does it's job well. It's a very comforting scent, quietly confident. I wouldn't say it was too loud either. It generally depends on how many sprays you apply. But it can definitely become intrusive and offensive if you over apply, the more you spray - the more harsh the scent becomes. But with about 2-3 sprays it gives you a nice, warm, gentle masculine scent bubble that stays around you for say 4-6 hours. On me anyways. I personally think this fragrance will be best suited to hot weather, I specifically bought it to take on holiday and wear on nights. Don't see it suiting day time in hot weather. But I can picture it adding a heap load of atmosphere to the nights away. Proud to have this unique fragrance in my collection.

May
08
2013
Smyle12

You don't "need to buy an original" because it's almost impossible to find one, and it's still an absolutely amazing scent, if not super-long lasting. I get about five hours. If you can only find the genuine, modern, article from Dior, you're still going to love it. Although Dior's Fahrenheit, may not be quite as intense and virile as it may have been in 1988, it's still an amazing and utterly unique fragrance, worth every penny.

ivis

my brother has this, i am disapointed from this scent, i was expecting something new and hot, it's very common and old.

May
06
2013
degauss

I have no personal relations to this scent and it doesn't speak to me much, but remove the first person point of view and it smells to me very pleasantly of a well-groomed man. Do you know that instance when you're in a middle of an involved conversation and it's indoors, warm, and you're in close proximity and gradually, increasingly you become aware of the scent carried off their skin by their body heat, and then can't ignore it after that? It's not necessarily sexual, not at all, but it strangely endears the man to you. Pleasant isn't bland, it's genuine, worthwhile and a great thing to be in this case.

kambelz

It's a masterpiece and a classic. It will always be in my top 10 favorites. The really earthy violet note and sweet floral honeysuckle combined make it smell like petroleum. It has a very car oil and "garage" type opening. It smells beautiful. If you like getting dirty and are a manly man, this is definitely for you. The middle contains a lot of leathery woods. The honeysuckle gets a little sweeter in the dry down.

Apr
16
2013
browne54

So this is what really happened. Perfumers Jean-Louis Sieuzac and Maurice Roger were on the set of the first Die Hard and requested Bruce Willis's undershirt after each day of filming. Combined with Steve McQueen's white undershirt from Bullitt (petroleum note) which they had air-tightly packed not knowing what to exactly due with in the Dior house they discovered Fahrenheit. Die Hard came out in 1988, same year as Fahrenheit, coincidence? But in all seriousness what a knockout, masterpiece, yada yada every award and title given for the fragrances list of accolades. So incredibly refreshing and masculine. I wish more fragrances of the modern day had the complexity and irrefutable masculine nature of Fahrenheit. The leather mixed in with the violet and greens make this such an appealing scent. Timeless from the house of Dior. The reformulation is not the same, despite triple-bonded benzine rings smelling great they are extremely flammable. So we are now left with a reformulated juice which still has the same essence and is by no means a slouch. However if you can ever get your grips on the vintage, DO NOT HESITATE.

Apr
10
2013
zuzuz

i am using Dior Farhenheit's base oil it is amazing and strong smell. i like it very much. it is a perfect fragrance men.

Annica

Is it coincidentally, or could it be that it is the new generation parfumistas who have discovered this perfume that was so incredibly popular in the 90s? Its really cool if thats the case. :)

2013
wesleyhclark

At first try I didn't get the petroleum/oil/gasoline notes, but now I do. I kind of like it!

What spoils things for me is the violet leaf. This fragrance and Grey Flannel has taught me something: I don't like violets or violet leaf!

One reviewer wrote, "Fahrenheit only asks one question. It asks it loud and it asks it clear. Do You Have The Balls?" Wow, really? This stuff isn't nearly that challenging. (Slumberhouse Norne is challenging.)

Not for me.

I like the bottle. Looks like a flame. Very nice.

It doesn't smell like a cologne, it smells like you have been working outside. Love it. Now if only I could convince my boyfriend to wear it...

Mar
30
2013
erik.siqueira

For me Fahrenheit is a journey. First of all i knew this frag when a I was a child and hated; now I have 27 years and learn to love this. The top notes are pure fuel, explosive, energetic, strong and for me timeless, so beautiful and addicted with leather and violet leaf. In the dry warm to much, mandarim orange, sandal and jasmin. After 5 hours the old school blend bring a impressive smell, masculine and consistent, close perfectly into the skin with musk and vetitver flowing, and the chamomile note. I just prove the reformulation, and is not too heavy, maybe the original has a pure fire in his juice, but I'm in love with this amazing frag.

Mar
24
2013
Mrbriangregory

i grew up with this scent but never really knew what it was. in the 80s, as a child, i had a neighbor who made a lot of money and he had this scent that followed him that was so memorable that when in the 90s i had a friend who's father made a lot of money i caught it again right away. because of this i just associated this fragrance with making a ton of cash. so i finally figured out what it was. and in my late teens it became my signature fragrance. i met a girl once who worked in a fragrance retail shop and said it was strawberry strawberry strawberry that came out of this bottle. i never got it. 15 years later, i still cant tell you what this smells like. power, confidence and money dont have specific fragrances. im ready to make this my go to again. we will always smell things differently, but for me personally, this is the most amazing and memorable scent that ive ever been so lucky to smell. i go out in la nuit de l'homme, varvatos, london, no one notices. but this stuff? everybody has something to say about this stuff.

Mar
24
2013
Mercurial Muzz

I used to wear Fahrenheit a lot in the winter, years ago. I loved it then, and, I still do now, even though all bottles are empty and I have no intention of replacing them. I think Fahrenheit is a highly devisive cologne, and I can understand why you either love it or hate it - it pulls no punches, doesn't hold back. And therein lies a lot of its appeal. Fahrenheit is not meek, will not go unnoticed. So much so, that I personally think this is to be worn winter only, and, one spray only. Anymore than that, and people will smell you a mile away! I kind of think of this as more of a 'bomb' than V&R Spicebomb. This certainly packs far more punch, and has explosive sillage. As I said, I love this, like most Dior colognes, but I don't know whether I will rekindle the love affair with a new purchase. Reformulated anyone? Please, tell me it isn't so!
I also remember my brother telling me years ago it smelt like fly spray! Interesting comment. I couldn't relate, but we're entitled to our opinions. So, for anyone considering this highly individual scent, these are my words of advice: wear it proudly. Stand tall. Wear in winter only. And, one full spray only. Fahrenheit, I miss you...

stjoseph777

2013
Lestat

Started wearing this fragrance about two months ago.Im surprised they didnt include benzoin as one of the note.Gasoline smell in this cologne is cause of this note. Yes it came out back in 80's but its still going strong.Make sure you try it first on your skin before you buy it. Its one of those fragrances that you will either hate it love it. Its green and clean smelling to me atleast. Dior makes excellent triggers so 2 or 3 sprays is more than enough.You do more than 3 you are on your own, keep headache med handy.For first few min you may not like the smell, but the drydown Amazing.Stays for a good 7 hours on my skin sometimes more.Projection is amazing. Wouldnt recommend this for summer unless 2 sprays. but this is perfect for spring fall and winter. Overall excellent cologne for a great price.

I take everything I said back, I just bought a bottle of this and absolutely love it...I was basing my previous post above on memory of this 10 years ago...I've had a change of heart....NOW I adore this fragrance and it will be a part of my collection for ages.
